PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS.
Mr. JENNINGS.- I desire to make a personal explanation. Last Tuesday, the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr.

Ward) stated that I had refused to take action upon a petition which I had received from returned soldiers who are inmates of Rand wink Military Hospital. I have received an unsolicited letter from the Coogee-Randwick sub-branch of the Returned Sailors and Soldiers Imperial League of Australia, which I read only because of its request that I should do so. It reads as follows: -
Mr. JohnJennings, M.P.,
Kensington-road,
Kensington.
Dear Sir,

We are writing this letter on account of various statements made regarding yon and the returned soldiers of this district. We want to take this opportunity of thanking you for the manyservices you have rendered the returned soldiers and for the great interest you have always displayed in their well-being. I, as secretary of this sub-branch and club, representing, in theRandwick municipality, over 700 diggers and ex-service men, definitely state that you have at all times given every attention and inquired thoroughly into every request made to you by any returned soldier, and many returned soldiers who have not been members of either the club or the sub-branch have appealed to you and interviewed youat your home andatyour business address.

I can,withwany thanks, recall the numerous occasions when you have helped our returned men in the matter of warservice homes, pensions, tram passes, funerals, and everything appertaining to returned soldiers. There is no man in public life that I know who has at all times done so much good and has spent 60 much time and money on the returned soldiers' movement.

My committee has expressly asked that this letter be written and be read in Parliament 60 as to definitely repudiate and contradict the most untrue and unfair statements made regarding your good self by some gentlemen who have been misinformed as to the true facts.
Thanking you and with kindest regards,
Yours faithfully,
Cougee-Randwick R.S. & S. Sub-Branch R.S. & S.I.L.A.
G. A.RUSSELL, Secretary.

I have received a further unsolicited letter, couched in similar terms, from the Marouhra-Kensington district sub-branch of the Returned Sailors and Soldiers Imperial League of Australia, which comprises over 300 members. Inquiries at the Randwick Hospital disclose that no petition was sent to me, and that I was not requested to take any action in regard to one. Honorable members will thus see that a misrepresentation has occurred, and that there is no foundation for the statement of the honorable member for East Sydney. I lay on the table the letters to which I have referred.
Mr.Curtin. - Does the honorable member propose to move " That the papers be printed"?
Mr. JENNINGS.-No.
Mr.Curtin. - Is the honorable member in order in laying the paper on the table.
Mr. SPEAKER.- The honorable member is not in order in doing so.

Mr. HUGHES.- The point raised by the honorable member for West Sydney is one of great importance, and the Government has been giving it serious consideration. Experts representing- the Department of Repatriation and the Pensions Department have been in collaboration, and the honorable member will be glad to know that, as the result, arrangements have been made whereby a pension already being received by an applicant will not be taken into consideration when assessing his income in order to determine the amount of another pension. ARBITRATION (PUBLIC SERVICE) BILL 1936.
Second Reading.
Mr. HUGHES(North SydneyMinister representing the Acting Attorney-General) [3.38]. - I move -
That the bill be now read a second time.

Seeing that this bill, and the Commonwealth Railways Bill 1936, relate to cognate matters, have I permission to include in my speech references to that measure ? It is desired that the two bills may be debated together.
Mr. SPEAKER.- The Minister and members who follow him may discuss the two bills.

Mr. HUGHES.-These bills propose to effect an alteration of the law relating to the tribunal which is to decide rates of wages and conditions of employment of employees in the 'Commonwealth Department, of Railways, other than per sons employed in a clerical capacity. The history of the struggle for a determination by an industrial tribunal of rates of wages and conditions of employment of railway employees in Australia is a long and interesting one, and, as it bears directly upon the measures before the House, I may be permitted briefly to review it. In 1904, when the first Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act was before Parliament, Mr. Andrew Fisher moved to include railway employees. The Government of the day strongly opposed the amendment. It was carried, and the Government was. defeated ; the provision was embodied in. the statute, and became law. In 1906, however, the constitutionality of the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth court to deal with employees of State, railways came before the High Court in the case of the Federated Amalgamated Government Railways and Tramways Service Association v. The New South "Wales Railways Traffic Employees Association; and the court held that the inclusion of railway employees was invalid. In 1911, the first Constitution alteration proposals were submitted to the people by the Labour Government of that day, and these included provisions giving Parliament power te legislate in respect of industrial disputes extending beyond a State, including disputes on State railways. Those proposals were rejected, by the people by a large majority. In 1913, second proposals for the alteration of the Constitution were submitted by the same Government, and on this occasion six bills were placed before the people, one of which provided for a jurisdiction for the settlement of disputes on State railways. Again the proposals were rejected, but by smaller majorities; the proposal relating to employees on State railways was- rejected by a majority of only 54,000, which represented about 1.74 per cent. The matter was not again referred to the people by way of referendum. The High Court, in the Engineers case, in 1920, rejected the principle upon which the High Court, then constituted of Chief Justice Griffith, Mr. Justice Barton and Mr. Justice O'Connor, had decided in 1906 against Mie validity of the inclusion of railway employees, and held that the Parliament had jurisdiction, and that the Arbitration Court could deal with disputes arising in connexion with 'State railways. It will be noted that the High Court thus decided that the power which the people had been asked to give was already possessed by the Parliament, and the Court of Conciliation and Arbitration proceeded to exercise that power. In 1930, the question of the validity of the court's jurisdiction in this matter was brought specifically before the High Court, in the case of Australian Railways Union v. Victorian . Railways Commissioners, and it was held that this was a valid exercise of its power.

I have been dealing with the principle of the fixation of wages and working conditions on "railways, the property of a State. I have reminded honorable members that the movement for the establishment of an independent tribunal for the purpose of fixing rates of wages and determining conditions of employment on State railways had continued over a number of years, and that when, at last, the right had been established, it was eagerly availed of.

I now come to the fixation of wages and conditions of employment of Commonwealth railway workers. In 1911 the first Public .Service (Arbitration) Act was passed : this act established a tribunal for the settlement of disputes and the fixation of wages and conditions of employment of all Commonwealth public servants. The tribunal selected under that act was the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, and it was given power to deal with intra-state, as well as interstate, disputes. All Commonwealth public servants, whether temporary or permanent employees, were eligible, and whether covered by the Commonwealth Public Service Act or not, were included in the act. The only exceptions were members of the naval and military forces. In 1920, a second Public- Service (Arbitration) Act was passed, which set up an entirely new tribunal, constituted of a Public Service Arbitrator. It transferred all pending cases, except part-heard cases, from the Court of Conciliation and Arbitration to the Public Service Arbitrator's court, and provided that its jurisdiction should apply to Commonwealth railway employees In 1917, when the Commonwealth railways were established, the rates of wages and the conditions of employment were determined by the Conciliation and Arbitration Court. At that time there was no other court to which the employees could apply. The Public Service (Arbitration) Act 1911 enabled them, as - I have explained, to invoke the special jurisdiction of that court. But upon the passage of the Public Service (Arbitration) Act 1920, the special jurisdiction of the Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, which enabled it to deal with intrastate, as' well as interstate, disputes, was swept away, and Commonwealth railways employees could not, under the 1911 act, get to the Arbitration Court a"t all, although they still enjoyed the same rights as other citizens, and could go to the Arbitration Court in its ordinary jurisdiction.

I now come to the point round which this debate must* turn. In 1911, as I have said, a tribunal had been set up which enabled the public servants of the Commonwealth to appeal for' the settlement of disputes, and for the determination of rates of wages and conditions of employment, to the Arbitration Court, which had a special jurisdiction for this purpose. In 1920, a new tribunal entirely was set up, consisting of the Public Service Arbitrator, whose jurisdiction was confined to disputes among Commonwealth public servants. From 1917, when the Commonwealth railways were opened, to 1935 - a period of eighteen years - the employees had the option of going either to the Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, or to the Public Service Arbitrator. For eighteen years, these employees, with the exception of the clerical staff, elected to submit their disputes to, and obtain redress of their grievances from the Arbitration Court, and completely ignored the Public Service Arbitrator. The one section of the railway service which did not do this was that engaged in a clerical capacity. They, from the beginning, appealed to the Public Service Arbitrator, and not to the Arbitration 'Court. We must assume that the organizations of Commonwealth public servants employed on. the railways of Australia knew their own business, and held the view that their interests were best served by the submission of their claims to the court to which the great majority of railway men looked for redress. In any case, for eighteen years they went to the Arbitration Court; but, on the 19th December, 1935, three weeks prior to the expiration of the period for which an award made by Judge Drake-Brockman was expressed to apply, the Australian Federated Union of Locomotive Enginemen lodged a memorial with the Public Service Arbitrator. On the 8th January, 1936, the Commonwealth Railway Commissioner filed a claim in the Court of Conciliation and Arbitration relating to the conditions of employment of members of not only the Australian Federated Union of Locomotive Enginemen, but also the Australian Workers Union, the Metal Trades Employees Union, the Wood Workers Union, and other organizations, ten in all. The compulsory conference arising out of this claim was held at Adelaide on the 17th January, Judge Drake-Brockman presiding. The Judge referred the dispute into court, but, at he request of some of the unions, a conference was held at Port Augusta, from the 25th to the 27th February, when an agreement; on the matters in dispute was arrived at with four of the organizations, the dispute as effecting the remaining organizations, including the Australian Federated Union of Locomotive Enginemen, being referred into court. The hearing of this case commenced at Port Augusta on the 22nd April last, and the proceedings were adjourned, pending the result of the proposed legislation.

This brings us to the present position. The whole of the facts have been stated, excepting the effect of the Statute Law Revision Act. The purpose of that measure, as honorable members may recall, was to deal with various obsolete acts, and to make drafting amendments in certain statutes. It was not intended to make any substantive amendments of the law, nor did the department, or the Minister in charge of the measure, understand that any such amendments had, in fact, been made. As far as T know, this happy ignorance of the effect of such an ill-regulated gesture was unknown even to the unions themselves, although about that the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Blackburn) will be able to speak with greater assurance than I. What the Statute Law Revision Act did was very simple; it struck out the three words " under that Act " which had appeared in the 1920 act limiting the right of public servants to appeal to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration under that act, and by doing so completely barred the public servants1 approach to the Arbitration Court. That was not intended, and the object of this amending bill is to restore to that extent the position as it was prior to the passing of the Statute Law Revision Act 1934.

To summarize the position as it now exists: For eighteen years the employees of the Commonwealth Railways have had th« option to go either to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration or to the Public Service Arbitrator. They have gone continuously and regularly to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration and never to the Public Service Arbitrator. In 1935, within three weeks of the termination of the current award, they submitted a memorial to the Public Service Arbitrator, and the Commissioner, as he was entitled to do, filed a plaint in the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. The judge of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court called a conference, and, in the case of four unions, brought the parties into' agreement. No agreement was reached in the case of other unions, and the judge referred the matter to the Arbitration Court. It is to be noted that, at the time when the Locomotive Engine-men filed » plaint before the Public Service Arbitrator, they were approaching the only tribunal to which they had access as the result, of the unfortunate operation of the Statute Law Revision Act. Theirs was the only union prevented from approaching the Arbitration Court. Al] the other unions could have approached, and con now approach, the Arbitration Court. When the conference took place in February it was open to every union, except the Locomotive Engine-men, to go to the Arbitration Court. Only one union was stopped from doing so.

The object of this legislation is to secure uniformity by restoring the conditions that have existed for the last eighteen years; conditions which have always had the full support of the railway men themselves. At any rate we are justified in assuming that the railway men, during those long years, were satisfied that they were receiving substantial justice at the hands of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court.
Mr. Makin.- That is very doubtful.

Mr. HUGHES.-I do not suggest for a moment that they had. all their desires granted to them - it is the lot of man not to get all that he desires - but they had the right to go before a court which determines the conditions, rates of wages and conditions of employment of 65 per cent, of the railway men of Australia, and because they elected to go to that court we must assume that they thought that it was a court which would give them a fair deal. What is the object of arbitration? As I conceive it, the principle underlying it, certainly the principle that moved the late Andrew Fisher to bring forward his amendment, and the principle which moved this Government to bring in the present legislation, and past governments, to introduce the amending arbitration acts of 1911 and 1920, and the modifications made from time to time, was an effort to find some better way for the settlement of disputes between employer and employee than resort to force. In order that that might be done, two things were necessary, the first of which was that the men should receive such reasonable wages and be employed under such reasonable conditions as would permit them to enjoy a fair share of the amenities of the state of civilization in which they found themselves, and the second that although a government-controlled railway service is entirely divorced from the capitalistic system inside which it operates, it is an integral part of the industrial system of Australia, and its efficient, economic and harmonious operation depends upon the rates and conditions fixed by the court or tribunal. The railways of Australia are run for the benefit and convenience of the public; .rates and conditions must therefore not only be such as to be fair and reasonable to the employees but also permit of the economic and efficient operation of the service. And it must not be forgotten that the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner has to compete with sea-borne traffic. Further, since the Commonwealth Railways are part of the railway system of Australia, rates and conditions should be, as far as possible, uniform. The employees on our railways must have reasonable rates and conditions, but every one who has had dealings with unions knows that the most potent cause of unrest is differential treatment. While, therefore, the workers must get a fair return for their labour, it is essential that the conditions, as far as possible, should be uniform. How can that uniformity be best assured? By the Arbitration Court, which the party opposite ever since this Parliament was established, believed to be the most effective means for the settlement of disputes and the most efficiently equipped to bring about harmonious and smooth-working in industry, or by the Public Service Arbitrator who has had no experience of railway working and who is not familiar with the conditions obtaining on State railways.
Mr. Beasley.- The right honorable gentleman will not say that industry has not been working smoothly for many years.

Mr. HUGHES.- What I am trying to ascertain is whether the better tribunal before which these men can go is the Commonwealth Arbitration Court or the Public .Service Arbitrator. It is perfectly true that the railway men of Western Australia and Queensland do not go before the Commonwealth Arbitration Court; they prefer their State industrial tribunals; but the point I emphasize is that all workers in those two States can go to the State industrial tribunals, whereas only Commonwealth public servants can go before the Public Service Arbitrator. His jurisdiction is specialized ; access to him is denied to the ordinary worker. I contend that what is good enough for the railway worker employed by the South Australian Government should be good enough for the worker in the Commonwealth railwaysservice.
Mr. Makin.- It is a different situation altogether.

Mr. HUGHES.- The point I am making is that a jurisdiction, which is good enough for the railway worker in a State should be good enough for the worker in the Commonwealth railways; a jurisdiction which has been good enough for Commonwealth railway employees for eighteen years, and which they themselves selected, ought to be good enough for them now. Since the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Makin) has seen fit to interject, I propose now to quote what the honorable member said in a former incarnation. Dealing with the Arbitration (Public Service) Bill, on the 7th September, 1920, the honorable member is reported in Hansard, volume XCIII., page 4238, to have said -

I have never been able to understand, or see any justification for, governments making laws in respect of private employers and employees, and being unwilling at the same time to include themselves and their employees within the scope of the same set of laws, lt is an inconsistency.
It is an inconsistency !

There arc laws made for compulsory observance by private individuals, but the Government which has made those laws is unprepared to apply them to itself and to those whom it employs. Concerning the question whether any proof is forthcoming that the main body of our public servants do not desire to be withdrawn from the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, I hold in my hand a document which represents the endorsement of that view by 30,000 public servants.
A Daniel come to judgment !

Not only has the subject matter of this document come before the executives of the various associations concerned, but it has been considered and approved also by the branches themselves. This memorandum was drawn up after due consideration, and as I have said has received branch as well as executive endorsement. It will be well for the Government, and honorable members generally, to heed the requests of this considerable body of public officials who desire to secure and retain no more than their just dues.
That was a strong body of opinion, because there were 30,000 public servants, and they demanded access, not to the Public Service Arbitrator, but to the Court of Conciliation and Arbitration.
Mr. Makin.- Sixteen years of experience have changed that view.

Mr. HUGHES.- I am reminding the honorable member of what he himself said, because, after all, it bears on this matter. 1 must be permitted to quote from another authority who has been strangely silent so far, but who, no doubt, will be moved to retort. I refer to the honorable member for Batman (Mr. Brennan), who is reported in Hansard, of the 7th September, 1920, volume XCIII., page 425S, to have said - "... My view is that the existing machinery of the Arbitration Act, giving equal justice - 'Which is ail we ask - to members of the Public Service exactly as to others outside the service, has been an automatic correction of the autocracy of the Public Service Coinmissioner on the one hand, while at the same time preventing undue influence upon the working of the Public Service. That was as nearly an ideal set of conditions as one could hope for : and those conditions were in existence when the repeal of the Arbitration Act, in its relation to the Public Service, was proposed, and the enactment of thu new measure was proceeded with .... . . . I sum up my objections to it in these words: - That this bill represents an attempt to segregate public servants unfairly; that it will put them under the jurisdiction of an arbitrator, who will be little more than an officer of the Public Service, who by reason of his tenure and position, will practically be a political representative, and who cannot be expected, in the circumstances to administer broad, even handed justice to all members of the service in that spirit in which the High Court Judges are prepared to administer justice, both to the members of the Public Service and to ordinary members of the community. And, in saying that of the members of the High Court Bench, I am not unmindful that these judges cannot be accused of undue Labour sympathies.".
I do not know that the argument could have been put more effectively than in those two citations.
Mr. Brennan.- I am amazed at my own conclusiveness.

Mr. HUGHES.- We have to consider whether any substantial injustice is likely to be done to the Commonwealth railway employees by the passage of these cognate measures. In my opinion, such a contention is absurd, for the railway employees are only being put where they have chosen to be for the last eighteen years, and where the employees of all the .State railway systems, excepting those of Queensland' and Western Australia, are to-day.

I come now to a consideration in respect of which I have a good deal in common with honorable gentlemen of the Opposition. Ever since I have been a member of this Parliament, I have struggled to secure uniform industrial conditions and uniform industrial control. I was under the impression that honorable gentlemen opposite believed strongly that the basic wage and standard hours of work should be fixed by one court for the whole of Australia. We shall turn our backs on that policy if we close the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration to the railway workers of the Common wealth. Admittedly, the court is not perfect. Being composed of judges with human limitations, it is not likely to satisfy everybody, but by reason of its long experience and familiarity with the details of our railway services it is likely to do more to effect, uniformity than any other authority.
Mr. Holloway.- Uniformity has not yet been achieved.

Mr. HUGHES.-That may be so, but this is the first time I have heard the honorable gentleman raise his voice in favour of a tribunal which would prevent the achievement of uniformity. To-day 65 per cent. of the railway employees of Australia are under the authority of the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration.
Mr. Barnard.- But a 40-hour week has not yet been achieved.
Mr. HUGHES.- The Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator has jurisdiction over only 1,500 railway men, and he will not be able to do anything effective to securea uniform 40-hour week.
Mr. Holloway.-The fact remains that after eighteen years of effort uniformity has not been achieved in our railway services.

Mr. HUGHES.- But we are moving towards it all the time, and the passage of these bills would be a step further in that direction. We are not likely to do anything useful to that end by removing the Commonwealth railway employees from the jurisdiction of the court. I remind honorable gentlemen that the Public Service Arbitrator has jurisdiction over only Commonwealth public servants. The honorable member for Hindmarsh and the honorable member for Batman referred in the extracts which I cited a few moments ago to what they described in general terms as an invidious and undesirable distinction between Commonwealth public servants and other workers in the community. Commonwealth public servants are entitled to justice, but not to special privileges denied other workers. All should be on the same footing.

What substantial injustice, if any, was done under the terms of Judge Drake-Brockman's award? I decline to entertain the suggestion that honorable gentlemen opposite are influenced by a spiritual urge and considerations of abstract justice to place the railway employees under another court. The organization with . which the honorable member for Maribyrnong is connected consists of about 120 or 130 members. Probably they consider that they could get better terms from the Public Service Arbitrator than from the Commonwealth Arbitration Court - and it is human nature to struggle for the best possible terms. But, if that is the situation, let us not talk about abstract justice.
Mr. Drakeford.-The union with which I am connected is not the only one which supports our view.

Mr. HUGHES.- But the honorable gentleman's union is the ringleader in this case. The Australian Workers Union and the other industrial organizations involved would not have thought of taking this course had not the honorable member's union suggested it. The other unions have said, in effect. "We will not let you stand alone; we will give you a hand." I am told that one objection to Judge Drake-Brockman's award' is that it does not embody provision for a district allowance. The judge, so I am informed, declined to include such a provision in the award, on the ground that it was the responsibility of the Railways Commissioner to deal with such a matter. I do not propose either to justify or attack the award in that regard; but it is a fact that the Commissioner has used his discretion in a way not detrimental to the men. He has adopted the existing allowances.
Mr. Drakeford.-But he did so only after the men threatened to cease work.

Mr. HUGHES.-The fact is that the district allowances have been adopted. We need not concern ourselves at the moment how that result was achieved. There are more ways of killing a cat than by choking it with butter. It has been argued that the adoption of the district allowance provisions by the Commissioner is unsatisfactory, because no sense of continuity is thereby secured. I therefore have pleasure in advising' honorable members that these provisions have now been embodied in a by-law, which having received Executive approval, is, therefore, part of the fabric of our legislation, and so beyond the Commissioner's power to alter.

One other point must be considered, although we cannot deal in detail with all the issues involved. It has been suggested to me that the Public Service Arbitrator is more likely to grant long-service leave to railway employees than is the Arbitration Court. I do not know what ground there is for that contention. I have never been brought into direct personal touch with the railway employees of the Commonwealth, although I was a member of a government which had a good deal to do with them years ago; but, so far as I know, long-service leave has never been asked for by the Commonwealth railway employees.
Mr. Drakeford.- It has been asked for on many occasions, and has always been refused.

Mr. HUGHES.-The Commonwealth Government realizes the desirability of giving general recognition to what it believes to be the view of this Parliament, that the Commonwealth railways are the people's property, and should be run in accordance with the conditions of, and complementary to, the railway systems of the various States. It also feels that wage rates and hours of labour should, as far as possible, be on a uniform scale and compatible with the standards which should apply in a highlycivilized community. The rates of wages and the conditions of work are for the Arbitration Court to determine; but I have ascertained that long service leave is generally granted, not by courts, but by Parliament. The Government has considered this subject, and I am authorized to say that steps will be taken to extend to Commonwealth railway employees the long-service leave conditions applicable to the railway service of Western Australia, which, I understand, are the most liberal in the Commonwealth, and provide for three months' long-service leave after ten years' service, an additional three months' leave after the next ten years' service, and an additional three months' leave after the next seven years' service. To meet the two points that have been raised, steps will be taken, first, to embody the district allowance conditions in the award, and, secondly, to provide for long-service leave by other appropriate action. It would be difficult for honorable gentlemen opposite to obtain such satisfactory concessions by any other means.

If a choice has to be made between the Commonwealth Arbitration Court and the Public Service Arbitrator's tribunal, the weight of argument is in favour of the court, which is the supreme industrial tribunal of the Commonwealth, and is, in effect, an industrial legislature. The awards of the court cannot be overridden in any State. In fact, no power in the Commonwealth can override them.
Mr. Blackburn.- Except the power of the Public Service Arbitrator.

Mr. HUGHES.- The Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration has power to make industrial laws of more far-reaching effect than any laws made by this Parliament, for anything that touches the wages or affects the conditions of the workers goes right home to the workers. The judges of the court are appointed for life, are independent of political censure, and are indifferent to political praise. The Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator occupies a very different position. He is appointed for a term; his is in fact a political appointment. His decision may be challenged and vetoed by one branch of this legislature, and, as honorable members know, it has been vetoed on several occasions. There is no factor which would induce any reasonable body of men to entrust their fortunes to a tribunal of that character, when there is available to them the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. The Arbitrator has had no experience of railway conditions : his determination, instead of allaying discontent, will provoke it. After much labour, we are approaching Port Pirie. Shortly - I speak prayerfully and earnestly - an engine will enter that station on the 4 ft. 8½ in. gauge. On the one side will be the triumphant engine-driver of the Commonwealth train, and on the other side the arrogant, contemptuous driver of the South Australian train. As they are doing the same kind of work, should they not receive the same pay? If they do not, trouble is bound to occur. Should not the same tribunal fix their rates of pay and the conditions of their employment? A sober survey of the situation will convince anybody of the desirability of what I am maintaining.
Mr.Drakeford. - Conditions enjoyed by other public servants should not be denied to them.
Mr. HUGHES.- I am a Commonwealth public servant, and so is the honorable member.' Should they be given what we receive? If not, why not?
Mr.Drakeford. - They should receive what all other Commonwealth public servants are given. I instance post office employees, and the clerical section of the railways service.

Mr. HUGHES.-The clerical section of the railways service found that it had most in common with the Public Service Arbitrator, whom it has approached for eighteen years. His jurisdiction extends over the whole of the Public Service, and embraces about 35,000 officers, at least 33,000 of whom are engaged in clerical and professional work. His functions are confined within limits which are fixed by statute and by regulation. The circumstances of the Public Service generally differ entirely from those of the railways service. The railways earn revenue, but the Public Service has only to spend it.

I shall not detain the House longer. I commend the measure to honorable members, not only by reason of what it is in itself, but also because of the garlands with which I have decked it. I hope that it will be approved of without unduly long discussion.

Mr. DRAKEFORD(Maribyrnong) [4.35]. - I appreciate the remarks of the right honorable gentleman in regard to the offer to apply long-service leave on the Western Australian basis. I have no wish to depreciate the value of that concession. I point out, however, that if the men had had their, rights, it would have been granted to them long ago. The right honorable gentleman has suggested that they should have asked for it. They have not only sought it from the Commissioner, who had the power to grant it, but have also asked the courts to make an award' in relation to it. Mr. Justice Powers stated clearly and definitely that the matter was one for either the Parliament or the employer to decide. The employer in this case, notwithstanding the fact that he is a large employer within Commonwealth Government's jurisdiction, denied the men this right which is granted to practically all other employees of the Government, and to the salaried section of the Commonwealth railways. The right honorable gentleman suggested that the men had gone to the court willingly for a period of eighteen years. On the last occasion the Commonwealth Commissioner of Railways took them there ; they did not go of their own volition. As I proceed I shall endeavour to correct the particulars of some of the incidents which the Minister has incorrectly related, without, I am sure, any desire to mislead.

The bill will be opposed by the Opposition, for the reason that it makes no contribution to the advancement of the principles of conciliation and arbitration in industrial matters, and no improvement of the machinery already in existence. We suggest that it represents an interference with that machinery and, instead of advancing, puts back the clock. It does not improve or widen the scope of the scheme which Parliament, after much expenditure of time and detailed consideration, set up, but seeks to narrow it and exclude from its benefits one particular section of Public Service employees who, instead of asking to be excluded, desire to make use of its provisions. If its objective were the setting up of industrial committees representing both the employer and the employees, by virtue of which those who actually operate the service and those who are charged with its management, could be brought around a table to confer and, if possible, arrive at agreement without the assistance of any outside authority; if it provided less complicated, and less costly machinery which might work more smoothly and rapidly, one could understand its introduction and the Government's desire to have it passed. But it does nothing of the sort. On the contrary, it takes away from railway employees the very provision which this Parliament said it was essential to make for the settlement of disputes between the instrumentalities of the Commonwealth on the one hand, and the employees of those instrumentalities on the other hand. The railway employees, as distinct from railway officers, who embrace more than ten-twelfths of the whole of the railway service, have no desire to be separated from the Commonwealth Public Service. Yet this bill proposes to make that separation in opposition to their wishes ! Any desirable or necessary improvement is in the direction of better facilities for the application of the round-table method, which does away with legal formula and procedure. The view of the Government as to the advisability of conciliatory methods being followed, was expressed in this Parlia- ment in 1920 and is recorded in the pages of Hansard. That publication contains some interesting passages. The Minister has already quoted some, and I shall recall to his memory others that he has overlooked. The Minister in charge of the original measure which this bill proposes to amend, explained that it was the hope of the Government that disputes would be settled by means of conciliation. At pages 4303 to 4358 of Hansard of the; 8th and 9th September, 1920, will bo found the report of the debate. The Minister is reported as having said -

Under this measure, where issues have been arrived at, the first step taken is the calling <if a conference . . . The desire is to suttie disputes so far as possible by these conferences ... If members of any organization are labouring under a grievance in respect to the conditions under which they are working they may bring the case before the arbitrator.

But the entire scheme of the bill is the exercise of conciliation. Every endeavour should lie made to arrive at a settlement of any dispute by conciliatory methods before enlistina the tribunal which is to bo created under the bill.

We are in entire agreement with that. We desire to proceed by conciliatory methods. We should much prefer to settle our differences around a table to having them settled by either the Public Service arbitrator or the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. But the Railways Commissioner, under pressure from go vernments like the present one, is compelled to make the attempt to run the Commonwealth railways according to business principles which cannot reasonably be applied to railways that are mainly of developmental or strategic value. In this same Hansard will be found the report of the debate on the Port Augusta to Kalgoorlie Railway Bill. It discloses the fact that honorable members on both sides of the chamber agreed that it was impossible to expect that railway to pay, and that it was always to be regarded as a strategic railway rather than one having any pecuniary value. Yet the Minister has just stated that the Railway Commissioner is expected to make the service earn revenue ! The amount of revenue it can earn is very small, compared with the interest bill he has to meet and the expenditure he has to incur, and lack of revenue should not prevent the employees getting a fair deal.
Mr. Hughes.- All that I said was that he was expected to earn it.

Mr. DRAKEFORD.- I think the Minister will agree that it is practically impossible for the East-West, or the North-South railway to earn as much revenue as will enable it to show a profit. Yet, when the employees approach the Arbitration Court - I speak from practical experience, because I have been their advocate for nearly twenty years - they are always confronted with the argument, not that a particular railway does not pay, but that the railway systems generally throughout Australia are non-paying concerns, and are the main factors in bringing about deficits. Consequently the court should not order higher rates of remuneration or an improvement of working conditions. In many respects the conditions of the railway men to-day are inferior to those which prevail outside the service. The difficulty is to find similar work with which proper comparisons may be made. When legislation was passed in 1.920, it provided a channel through which public servants and railway employees could obtain rectification of injustices or grievances. The point most frequently stressed in that debate was, that there should be a separate jurisdiction for the Public Service generally. The honorable member for Darling Downs (Sir Littleton Groom) figured very largely in that debate, because it was his duty to pilot the measure through this House. He quoted legal opinion which went to show definitely and clearly that it was intended to cover all Commonwealth railway employees, and that they should have whatever privileges were enjoyed by other public servants in relation to arbitrational jurisdiction. The present bill proposes to alter the law to the disadvantage of a particular section. The effect of it will be to place the railway men in a separate category compared with -the rest of the Public Service; and not all of those employed in the railway services, because it will leave the 'clerical and professional officers, the higher paid and more favoured salaried section, untouched, applying the embargo only to the lower daily paid section.

The Minister has gone to considerable trouble in an endeavour to show that such a course of action is justified. I realize that if the bill is made a purely party measure, and members are not free to exercise their own judgment, it will be passed whether it inflicts injustice or not. We hope that the Government will not make it a party matter, and that it will be prepared to permit its supporters to listen to the arguments advanced, and then come to a decision. We cannot accept the dictum that draws these men out of the Public Service and places them in a watertight compartment. I feel sure that the House will vote for a continuance of the existing state of affairs. The only justification which appears to be offered in support of the alteration to the law is the fact that the men would have the choice of either the Arbitration Court or the Public Service Arbitrator, and that the worker has two choices, while the employer has only one. That is not the case.
Mr. Hughes.- It was the case for twenty years.

Mr. DRAKEFORD.- If that aspect is examined it will be found to be anything but substantial. The Commissioner is clothed with power to fix rates and conditions of service, which, at the outset, he, in fact, does. He determines the reward which shall be offered for the labour he requires. The worker, if he is not satisfied with the rates and conditions fixed, can, by drawing up a log of claims and lodging it in the form of a memorial to the Arbitrator, have the rates and conditions fixed reviewed. It is practically a form of appeal to an independent authority from the employer's decision, but when the Arbitrator has made his determination the employer has the first right of interpretation. He applies the award, or what he thinks the award means, and if he is not satisfied with the way in which it works out, then he can apply to the Arbitrator for it to be varied. The worker has exactly the same right as to variation, and the employer is at no disadvantage whatever. He is exactly in the position of any other head of a department of the Public Service.
Mr. Hughes..- He cannot file a memorial.

Mr. DRAKEFORD.- No ; but he fixes the wages and conditions of the worker in the first place, and when an award is given, he can apply for its variation from end to end. Any contention that may be advanced that it was never intended that the employee should be able to use both jurisdictions, that of the Arbitration Court, and that of the Public Service Arbitrator, is disposed of, I think honorable members will agree, by the following extract from Hansard- of the 22nd July, 1920, covering the debates when the Arbitration (Public Service) Bill was under discussion in the Senate. Sir George Pearce, who was then Minister for Defence, was in charge of the bill.
Senator Drake-Brockman.- Under this bill they must go to the court provided by this measure ?

Senator Sir GEORGEPEARCE.- Not necessarily. Some went to the General Court of Arbitration, and others to the court established under the Arbitration (Public Service) Act, but the Commonwealth Government laid it down as a principle, that, in the Public Service, they would obey Arbitration Court awards. If an organization obtained an award affecting the employees in one of our Government factories in the General Court of Arbitration, the Government would obey that award. So far no practical difficulty has been experienced.
It may be thought a coincidence that that question was asked by the senator who, as a judge of the Arbitration Court, has been, and is now, dealing with their cases.

No practical difficulty has been experienced since that time. Yet this Government wants to change the whole procedure. It is only now when the railway men have placed a memorial before the Public Service Arbitrator that, any attempt is made to make a change. This Government is trying to take away from the railway men rights which a Government of a similar calibre gave to them many years ago.

When the bill was under discussion iri this House, that aspect of the matter was again debated, and the Minister in charge of the bill, the honorable member for Darling Downs, did not attempt, to suggest that the employees did not have the right to go to either tribunal. The essence of the legislation, which was passed in 1920, was to separate all the public servants of the Commonwealth from workers outside the Public Service, and to place them in a position in which they could have their claims against the rates of pay and conditions of service in operation, if they were dissatisfied with them, heard, considered and decided by an independent authority. The following is another extract from the Hansard report of the debate which took place in the Senate on the 22nd July, 1920, on the Arbitration (Public Service) Bill. Senator Sir George Pearce said - lt may he asked: What are the reasons for the i, ill ? In the first place the Government thinks that as the conditions and nature of employment in the Public Service are different from private employment, it is essential n> provide an industrial tribunal for all mutters in dispute.

That extract emphasizes the differences between public servants and private employees. The railway men are still in public employment, and that was the essence of the bill when it was introduced. The present bill puts the men on a totally different basis.-

The point as to whether the legislation covered the railway employees of the Commonwealth was raised by Senator Thomas when the bill was brought down for consideration in the Senate, as is shown by the following extract from page 305S of Hansard of the 22nd July, 1920 :-
SenatorThomas. - T understand, from reading clause 3 of the bill, that all public ser vants, temporary as well as permanent, will come under the operation of this measure.
Senator PEARCE-That is so.

SenatorThomas. - Does that include employees of the Public Service in departmentsnow under the Public Service Commissioner and also those employed in the Naval and Military Department and under the Commonwealth Commissioner for Railways?
Senator PEARCE.- No. It will not include those employees under the Commissioner for Railways or in the Naval and Military Departments.

Apparently some doubt existed in. the mind of the Minister, however, for progress was reported and the debate was adjourned until he had obtained an opinion on the matter from the Crown Law authorities, which set all doubts at rest. I quote further from the report of the parliamentary debates with respect to that opinion. Senator Sir George Pearce said -

When a previous clause was under discussion, Senator Drake-Brockman raised a question which is affected by this clause also, and 1 am afraid, in replying, I was under a misapprehension. The honorable senator asked whether it was clear what organizations could have access to the Arbitrator, and I drew attention to the definition clause. As thai: matter affects this clause also, I asked leave, to report progress, so that I might be fully informed on the point. The Crown Law officers advise as follows:-

The point has been raised as to whether the bill covers persons employed on the Commonwealth railways, in the harness factory and persons employed in shipbuilding operations carried on by the Commonwealth. '"'The Public Service" is defined as including "' the Public Service of the. Northern Territory and the Territory for the Seat of Government, and the service of any public institution or authority of the Common wealth ", and " all persons employed in any such .service . . whether under the Commonwealth Public Service Act 1!)02-1!)1S or not . ." This definition is exactly the same, as that appearing in the present Arbitration (Public Service) Act 19i1 In my opinion, the words ' Public institution or authority of the Commonwealth " would include the Commonwealth railway service, the Government Harness Factory, and shipyards carried on by the Commonwealth. If this interpretation is correct, there is no doubt that the bill covers the persons referred to. In regard to persons employed on Commonwealth railways, there is another ground for holding that they are covered by the bil!. ThiCom'monwealth Railways Act 1917, section 47. enacts that the Arbitration (Public Service) Act shall apply to the railway servants. Clause 2 (5) of the bill provides that any reference in any net to the

Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1011 shall be read as a reference to the bill. It is quite clear, therefore, that the bil. applies to the railway service. Although the employees on the Commonwealth railways and in the harness factory are entitled to form associations and to become registered under the Arbitration (Public Service) Act, I understand that they have not largely availed themselves of this right. Apparently most of them prefer to belong to large associations such as the Australian Workers Union, the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemens Union and the Saddlers Union which are registered under the ordinary provisions of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
Senator Sir GeorgePearce went on to say-

I u-m sorry that, the question being sprung upon mc in committee, I was not fully informed upon the point, and, to some extent, misled the committee. However, it is within the competence of the committee to deal with this matter, which affects the whole of the bill. It is only right that the committee should know that the bill also covers these industries carried on by the Commonwealth as part of the Commonwealth service.

No attempt was made at that time to exclude the railway men, because it was thought right and proper that they should go to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator. Now, when the railway men make some attempt to go there, this Government seeks to prevent them. There seem to be powerful influences behind the Government in seeking to prevent these men from getting what they believed they probably would get from the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator; that is, a shorter working week. I am not suggesting that the gentleman has made up his mind on the point - he has not had the opportunity so far - but all other Commonwealth workers comparable to the railway workers enjoy a 44-hour week. That is the basis on which this claim is being made. But when they move to get it, the whole machinery of the nation i» thrown into operation against them.
Mr. Brennan.- It seems like interference with the course of justice.

Mr. DRAKEFORD.- The railway employees desire to be put on the same basis as postal employees. There are only three Arbitration Court judges, and it requires a full court of three to alter hours. In 1927 those three judges said that they were not prepared to alter these hours for railway men, and there is no indication that their minds have since been changed. It also looks as if this Government is prepared to move heaven and earth to prevent us from achieving a shorter working week in the railway service. If the public knew that it was using its legislative powers as it is doing to-day, they would realize that it does not believe in anything less than a 48-hour week, although, at Geneva, its delegate was instructed to support the 40-hour week convention.

It is clear that the Arbitration (Public Service) Bill was intended to cover railway employees, and no attempt was made to amend the original legislation to exempt them or to prevent them from obtaining any benefit which the bill conferred. If it was good for public servants it was good for all of them. No one argued that the railway men should be left out. There are honorable members opposite who were members of this chamber in 1920, who took part in the debate, and none of them then sought to do what the bill now proposes to do. No one thought of suggesting, or of urging, that the Commonwealth railway employees should be excluded from any benefits conferred by the act. The Minister said that since we have not exercised our right for eighteen years, we do not need that right. Mr. Justice Powers, in 1919, made an award under the Public Service Arbitration Act for the very men I have the honour to represent in the courts. He said -
The matter comes before me under a plaint filed by the claimant organization and one authorized by section 47 of the Commonwealth Railways Act 1917.

The history is clear. In 1920, when the High Court decision alluded to by the Minister gave the railway men the right to go to the Arbitration Court, we set about organizing the men in a body which would represent the whole of the locomotive men's organizations throughout Australia. By 1924, we had done that, as the Minister in charge of the bill knows. In 1917, a railway strike disorganized the whole of the railways organizations, and loyalist organizations were set up in New South "Wales by the then Government. I was given the honour of attempting to re-organize the shattered forces of the union, and when I went to New South Wales in 1923, only about 550 were members of the organization. By 1924 the members totalled 2,670, and to-day more than 3,500, or 97 per cent, of the men eligible to join the ranks are members. Following upon this successful reorganization a plaint was filed with the court, and it included the whole of the locomotive men in Australia, except those in Western Australia and South Australia. Mr. Justice Powers refused to include Queensland in the award, destroying the chance of obtaining the uniformity which the Minister has mentioned so much. Later on, New South Wales was released from the federal award. The locomotive men approached the court twice, and in 1930 the Arbitration Court set aside the awards and left the men at the mercy of the employers. There is no doubt about that. It took away the protection which had previously operated in regard to the treatment of employees, and made conditions much worse in many respects. The men were forced by the logic of experience to realize that if awards were to be set aside when they were most needed, because the employers wanted it, then they were relying upon something which did not afford any substantial protection. The only one to whom that did not apply was the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner, but the railway men, like other public servants, came under the provisions of the Financial Emergency Act. They did not want to go back to the court ; the Commonwealth {Railways Commissioner took them to the court, and it was tie who got the award. That award, to the extent that it affected the Commonwealth division, imposed serious reductions in regard to the margin for cleaners and firemen, and also made worse the previously existing condition in regard to such matters as overtime, where the penalty was reduced from time and a half after ten hours to time and a quarter from ten to eleven hours The conditions in regard to relay working, which had existed right from the inception of this method of working on the North-South lines, were also seriously curtailed; and whereas previously Jull pay was given for all time travelling on relay, Judge Drake-Brockman reduced this to half time. In regard to the. guaranteed fortnight, it was the previous practice to pay a guarantee of 96 hours, exclusive of any Sunday time, or Sunday time penalty that was worked, whereas the award included both the Sunday time and the Sunday time penalty as part of the guaranteed 96 hours fortnight. The mixed functions clause was altered from two hours, and extended to four hours. Tie clause dealing with seniority and promotion was so framed as to limit the credit of higher grade work to 96 hours a fortnight. The district allowances were ordered to be paid until the 30th June, 1933, and no longer, and thereafter the payment of such allowances was to be at the discretion of the employer.

I know that the long-service leave is usually dealt with by regulation, or by. act of Parliament. The mostimportant thing was that when Mr. Justice Powers made the award in 1923, he gave the men working on the Commonwealth railways some consideration because they were working under special conditions. The Minister knows something of those conditions. The men working on the line from Alice Springs, to Kalgoorlie cannot be transferred to any such places as Sydney, Adelaide, Perth or Brisbane, as can the men working on inland sections of State railways. The court, in recognition of this fact and other disadvantages, prescribed a rate which gave the men ls. 3d. above cost of living figures, and, in addition, a district allowance was fixed according to the area in which they lived. Mr. Justice Starke also had previously laid it down that the men should get 6d. above cost of living figures, and Deputy President Sir John Quick let those provisions stand as he had found them in the Powers award of 1927; but Judge Drake-Brockman swept all that aside, and there was an uproar from one end of the line to the other. This was particularly evident at Port Augusta, where many of the employees are located. The Minister in charge of the bill says that we should resort to conciliation and arbitration, but when the award came out the men were indignant, and threatened to stop work, saying that they would risk the consequences. The union officials, including myself, pleaded with them to remain at work, pointing out that in the end they would probably injure themselves, and drive traffic to the coastal shipping services. We explained that there were channels through which they could have their grievances rectified, and we asked them to keep on working in the hope that matters would be adjusted later on. We had in mind the fact that they still had access to the Public Service Arbitrator, but now the Government has brought clown this bill to prevent them from having access to that official, and the men feel that they have been " sold a pup ". What faith can they have in the advice or the judgment of their officials after that, if this bill, which deliberately takes away the right on which they relied for peaceful settlement of their claims, is allowed to pass?

Having been over both the transcontinental and central Australian lines by means other than those followed by the ordinary traveller, who gets nothing more than a flying glimpse of conditions as he passes through, and having come into touch with the families in their homes, and with the men in their camps, both along the track from Alice Springs to Kalgoorlie, and in the trains where some of them 'live while the trains are being worked, T could, I think, paint a picture which would interest honorable members, and perhaps enlist their practical sympathy for the Commonwealth railway employees and those dependent on them. I do not, however, desire to take advantage of my position here to go into those matters in detail, but I desire that the Government shall not withhold justice by the passing of this bill, and the other one which is complementary to it. There is no doubt that it was intended to include railway men within the number of those who enjoy right of access to the Public Service Arbitrator, but when they sought to exercise their right, and not till then was the machinery of the legislature of the nation put into operation to take away l'ights which the same machinery was used to provide. If this bill is passed, the railway men will feel that, because of their observance of awards which they did not, and still do not, believe to be fair, their unswerving recognition of the prin- ciple of arbitration is being unreasonably imposed upon.

Before the men became members of my organization, there were frequent strikes. The honorable member for Grey (Mr. McBride) and the honorable member for Darling Downs (Sir Littleton Groom) will remember that. I was a member of a deputation which waited upon the honorable member for Darling Downs when he was Minister for Works and Railways to discuss matters relating to a strike which occurred in 1917 or 1918. That was long before the men became members of the locomotive men's union, but. after that they gave up the right to strike, because they believed that there existed channels through which they might have their grievances redressed. The Government has not attempted to show that there has been any abuse of the right to approach the Arbitrator. No attempt has been made to prove to the House that the railway men have, since that right was given to them, attempted to flout or evade the law which provided it. The most that the Government can put forward is that they have not availed themselves of the jurisdiction.
Mr. Hughes.- There have been thirteen awards connected with the East- West line, and the Commissioner has initiated only one.

Mr. DRAKEFORD.-That may be so, but probably a dozen different unions went to the court at different times. On the last occasion, however, it was the Commissioner who approached the court, and obtained ' an industry award covering all the employees. The employees did not want to go there; it was the Commissioner who took them. The locomotive men did not want to come in, but the judge refused to exclude them. Thus, it will be seen that it was not the Commonwealth railway men who went to the Arbitration Court in 1932, after the awards had been set aside. It was the Railways Commissioner who served a log on the union, in which he sought reduced wages and worse conditions. He asked the court to reduce the basic wage fixed by Mr. Justice Powers, which had been in operation' for nine years, and he asked that other things, which had been provided for in the award of the court, should b*>- left to him to decide. In self-protection the unions lodged counter claims, but at the conclusion of the case the men found that, in many instances, 'they had suffered reductions. Every adult on the job working on a daily-paid basis lost the ls. 3d. a day which the award of the court had previously provided, and for some grades for which margins higher than the basic wage were previously fixed, the margins were either reduced or wiped out. The special recognition which prevailed in the Commonwealth Railways, operating on a route where there was no seaport town other than Port Augusta, and where the climate was severe, was wiped out. This recognition, which afforded some compensation to the men and their families, was withdrawn by the award of the court, and even the district allowances originally granted by the department, and afterwards incorporated in the awards, were, at the request of the Commissioner, left to his discretion. I recollect the Commissioner's advocate saying, during the hearing of the case, that the allowances were too high. I do not suggest that every alteration of the award was to the disadvantage of the men, but the benefits they derived from it were for comparatively few. The award, as a whole, was received by the great majority of the men with tremendous disappointment, and was regarded as a severe set-back from which they would seek the earliest means of escape. Some of the more active spirits desired to resort to direct action, and threatened to do so, arguing that adherence to arbitration had created a false impression in the minds of those in authority; but the officials of the various organizations counselled them to stay their hands. I am not speaking now of the locomotive men only, though I was more closely associated with them than with the others. I know that, had we said the word, a strike would have occurred, resulting in great loss to the department, and great inconvenience to the public. This bill is the reward which the men have received for the patience they displayed.
The Minister in charge of the bill, in his book The Case for Labour, published in 1910, states on page 138 -

The wage-earners have fought bitterly and long for better conditions; without unions they could Iia vo done nothing. Unions have done much. But they will not do everything. As the cause of bad industrial conditions is to be found in bad laws, it is by legislative reform that permanent and effective improvement of the wage-earner's condition is to be found.

Unfortunately, the right honorable gentleman who wrote those lines is now the agency through which those rights are to be taken away. I venture to suggest that, if that section of the employees which it is now proposed should be deprived of their rights was large in numbers, and was spread throughout Australia instead of being confined to only two of the States, both the Government and the Minister would have paused before proceeding with this measure, if, indeed, in those circumstances, such a measure would ever have been drafted. The .political steam-hammer is being used to crack a nut of small size, but of great significance. This is being done as a matter of expediency in the interests, not of the Government itself, but of some influential authority, which sees in the present system a prospect of the railway employees being placed on a similar footing to their fellow employees in other branches of the Public Service. The principle of separating the public servants of the Commonwealth from the rest of the workers, insofar as the regulation of their wages and working conditions are concerned, was fought for by this Government. That principle was evolved by the same kind of political thought as that which now controls this Parliament, yet now, for reasons ot expediency only, the Government asks the House to abrogate that principle.

What justification can be offered for the separation of 1,000 men in one particular branch from the rest of the Commonwealth Public Service? The Minister in charge of the bill put forward the argument that, as railway men generally go to the federal court, Commonwealth railway employees also should go there. It will be found, on inquiry, that the railway men in Queensland and Western Australia, who number approximately 21,000, do not apply to that court for redress of their grievances. The New South Wales locomotive men, numbering, at the minimum, 3,500, are working under a State award, and there is a considerable disparity between the margins fixed by the State court and the Federal court for two important sections of the men, the electric train drivers and the cleaners. The margin fixed for the electric train drivers was increased from 7s. to Ss. a day by the State court, while almost at the same time the federal court reduced the margin from 7s. to 6s. The State court increased the margin for engine cleaners, but the federal court wiped it out. The federal court, itself, has referred the railway men, who are members of the Australian Railwaymen's Union, to a State tribunal, the Victorian Railways Classification Board.

It is claimed by the Australian Railways Union that its membership is approximately 17,000, but, as some of the members may be covered by awards given for artisans, it may be reasonably stated that the Victorian Railways Classification Board will deal with the conditions of approximately 15,000 railway employees. The action of referring the. claims of the Railway Commissioners and the railway employees to the Victorian Railways Classification Board was taken by His Honour Judge Drake-Brockman, under section 36 of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act. He will have the final voice, but the work of investigation will be done by the State tribunal. When the railway employees desire the Public Service Arbitrator, instead of the court, to investigate and decide their case, they are confronted by this bill, which proposes to prevent it.

The Public Service (Arbitration) Act 1920 was designed to provide the advantage of preventing varying decisions leading to trouble and difficulty in administration within the Public Service. How can it reasonably be expected that some of the Commonwealth Government's employees will be satisfied with conditions of employment which are greatly inferior to those applying to the great majority of the employees? Can they be expected to view without resentment the fact that the Commonwealth Railways officers are provided for -by the awards of the Public Service Arbitrator, whilst they are to be prohibited from having their case dealt with by that authority? As far back as 1920 the Public Service

Arbitrator, then a different person from the gentleman now occupying the position, ordered 44 hours a week in his awards for daily-paid workers. A 44- hour week did not become general until a somewhat later stage, but it is practically the standard for daily-paid workers covered by awards of the Arbitrator, and it has been so for a decade. The awards provide shorter hours for men who are on night duty, and .who work broken shifts, and they allow for overtime rates after a standard day has been worked. The Federal Court allows the employer to work men up to ten hours in any day without any overtime payments, and then a rate of only time and a quarter prevails up to eleven hours. It is quite possible for men to work ten hours and travel for work purposes up to twelve, fourteen or more hours, during which period they can be called upon for work at any minute, without receiving any overtime payment, because the travelling is at a passive rate which does not carry penalties. For men operating trains, the federal court, at the request of the employer, decreased the overtime rates, after ten hours work, from time and a half to time and a quarter, and the same court has indicated thai, if the desire to have a weekly day of rest, asked for by the men, is granted, it might "have to consider a further extension to the employers' claim for consideration. Whilst, in most parts of the world, efforts are being made to prevent overtime, and thus .spread employment over as wide a field as possible, the liberty of the employer to work men overtime has been extended.

A factor that is always stressed in the court is the economic position of the railways throughout Australia. The deficits, wilfully created in most cases by inadequate freight charges and by the building of lines for developmental purposes to places which it was known beforehand would not provide .an adequate revenue, are trotted out by the skilful advocates of the departments as showing that no improvement should be given to the employees, if the economic conditions of the railways are to be given due consideration. Enhanced land values created by the building of the lines do not pass to the credit of the Governments representing the people of the States on whose behalf the lines have been constructed. A rake-off is provided for the land-holder or speculator when the land is sold at enhanced values, but if the land becomes unprofitable to work, it leads to a demand for a reduction of transportation rates and for subsidies to the men on the land. Revenue derived from the opening up of land for exploitation, such as timber royalties, and land tax, where it operates, goes not to the Railways Department, but to other departments. If the land served by the railways, including that, in city areas, were subject to reasonable taxation, and the proceeds were applied as a set-off to reductions of freight and fares, the railways as a transport agency would continue to have pride of place, and would be held up to the public as a substantial benefit, instead of the hopeless burden they are depicted as being to-day. The farmers would benefit, and so would the public and the railway workers. We should not have the spectacle of railway managements being forced to plead financial losses to prevent the employees from getting fair treatment.

The Commonwealth railways, above all others, were never expected to pay. The Transcontinental line was built to provide a service between the western and eastern half of the continent as an obligation to the people of Western Australia on their entering the federation, and as a provision for defence purposes. The Alice Springs railway is an extension of a line which was known to be a hopeless burden when it ran only to Oodnadatta, but it was completed in fulfilment of a promise made to South Australia. Only by the development of large gold or oil-bearing territory could it prove commercially profitable. Yet those working on this North-south line, which over almost every mile of it traverses desert country, are confronted with its failure to produce a profit when their wages and working conditions are being considered, and its deficits are added to the others to make up a weight of evidence against them getting shorter hours or improved conditions. This line is as much a national service as that rendered by the Meteorological Department, the Defence Department and others which spend much but produce little direct revenue. Yet the railway men are to be put into an inferior class to their colleagues in those departments, and are to become Commonwealth Service pariahs or outcasts!

No one claims that the majority of Commonwealth employees .are too well treated through being given a 44-hour week, but this Government is denying the railway men their chance of obtaining it. District allowances are fixed for all branches of the Public Service, except Commonwealth daily-paid railway men. on a common basis, in accordance with climatic disadvantages, geographical location, distance from centres of population, and concomitant lack of social amenities. No distinction is made between post office officials and officers of the Department of the Interior, yet there is a definite and wide distinction between the district allowance for postal workers and that of railway workers at, say, Alice Springs. In that town we have two sets of employees, both working for Commonwealth instrumentalities, the railway employee receiving an allowance of ls. a day, or £18 5s. per annum, and the postal employee receiving £50 a year, if married, and £30 a year, if single. I accept the Minister's assurance as to the willingness of the Government to see that railway employees do not suffer in regard to the district allowance; but I point out the disparity in the payments made to workers in the Postal Department, as compared with other departments. In addition to that, the district allowances for other than railway men are fixed, and cannot be withdrawn at the will of the employer, as is the case of the railway men under the award of His Honour Judge Drake-Brockman. The employees, other than railway men,- are provided for under a common rule of the Public Service arbitration tribunal with respect to pay while on sick leave. They have long service leave or furlough. Even temporary employees are so provided for by the Public Service Arbitrator, whilst permanent employees of the railways are not so covered. All railway employees in the State services throughout Australia are provided for in respect of long-service leave, with the exception of Victoria. In Western Australia and South Australia, where almost the whole of the Commonwealth railway employees live, the State railway employees get long-service leave.
It will be found, on reference to Hansard of the 3rd September, 1920, page 43S5, that the honorable member for Darling Downs (Sir Littleton Groom), when Minister for Works and Railways, said- -

It will bo found in operation to be a very beneficial piece of legislation. It takes away no rights from anybody. It gives the public servants rights, and a means of having their rights determined and benefits conferred upon them. It simply appoints an Arbitrator, with all the powers and jurisdiction that the judge had under the act of 1911.
SirJoseph Cook. - And it will give the public servant's more and better facilities to have their cases heard.

Sir LITTLETONGROOM.- Yes, and it offers the advantage that, instead of having a number of varying decisions leading to trouble and difficulty in administration, the. Service will have one tribunal where the whole of their rights and privileges will be promptly worked out as a consistent whole.

Instead of creating friction, I believe that the bill will create a greater amount of confidence in the administration of the Public Service, through the officers having a just tribunal to deal with their rights.
Mr. Hughes.- The railway employees did not go to the Public Service Arbitrator for sixteen years.

Mr. DRAKEFORD.-The locomotivemen went twice -to the court, and were taken back to it by the Commissioner, after awards which they had previously obtained had been set aside by that court. Then they, went to the Public Service Arbitrator. Surely the Government still wants to avoid the disadvantage of " varying decisions leading to trouble and difficulty in administration ". Surely the Ministry, and those honorable members who support it, desire to bring about conditions which, instead of creating friction, will cause " a greater amount of confidence in the administration of the Public Service, through the officers having a just tribunal to deal with their rights ".

If they do, they must vote against the second reading of this bill, which takes away the right of access to a tribunal set up by a government of the same type as that which they support.
