If honorable members opposite can but put themselves for a little while in the place of the men * affected, they will have no difficulty in arriving at the view that the bill is unwarranted, and that much more substantial reasons will have to be given, if indeed, any sound reason can be found, for the carrying of a measure which w restrictive in its action, repudiates the principles contained in the bill sought to be amended, is harsh, and is manifestly unjust to a law-abiding section of the Public Service whose interests it affects. The railway men are aware that the Public Service Arbitrator awards a 44-hour week, and they know now, since the Commonwealth Arbitration Court has had the opportunity to deal with the matter, that it does not do so. In such circumstances, how can it be expected that they will be other than dissatisfied ? Where is the " consistent whole which the Minister in 1920 said would be one of the advantages arising from the appointment of a Public Service Arbitrator ?

It will be seen that the inference that railway men, as a rule, seek the aid of the Arbitration Court, rather than that of other tribunals, is not correct. The Commonwealth railway men knew that there was another channel open to them, and they made themselves familiar in a general way with what results had followed, from the use of that channel. They saw that their fellow public servants in practically all other branches of the Commonwealth, activities - daily-paid workers like themselves - obtained a 44-hour week without reduction of pay, and payment when off on sick leave; that the provision of district allowances was not left to the discretion of the employer; and that they were provided for in the matter of long-service leave or furlough. The employees did not always get what they claimed, but they accepted what they did not like as cheerfully a 3 they could, and looked with some hope, down an avenue provided by the law, upon a distant and more alluring future.

This year the Government has brought forward a proposal to prevent " the rights and privileges of the Public Service "' being " worked out as a consistent whole ". .Surely those honorable members who supported that principle in 1920 will not stand for its abrogation now. According to Hansard of the 3rd September, 1920, page 4200, the right honorable member who has introduced the present bill stated in this House - 1 repeat that all the bill proposes to do is to create a Public Service Arbitration Court. . . Honorable members must admit that this will be a far better method of dealing with Public Service affairs than that which exists to-day, where a judge of the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration is required to give so much of his attention to a Public Service matter arising as he may be able to spare in the course of dealing with industrial problems emanating from any and every industry throughout the land. . . . This is a bill which violates no precedent and introduces no innovation. It rests upon abundant precedent.

And yet this same gentleman, representing the Acting Attorney-General in a similar kind of government is now introducing legislation which is taking away the advantages derived from the bill which he introduced in 1920. When one reads the debates relating to the creation and development of the system of Public Service arbitration, in which the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) has played so important and so great a part in the past, and when one goes back into the records and realizes how stern a fight he made for the principle that all public servants should have access to the tribunal, one cannot help but marvel at the extraordinary changes which time and political circumstances have brought about. I feel sure that the right honorable gentleman cannot be happy in the task which is placed in his hands to-day. I feel certain that his heart cannot be in li is job, and that he does not willingly sacrifice all the things for which he stood throughout the years, in an endeavour, as a mere matter of political expediency, to wreck the principles on which the system of conciliation and arbitration in the Public Service was founded. I ask that consideration be given to the question of deferring this bill until the Government has given further thought to its effect on a comparatively small number of worthy citizens rendering faithful and efficient service under unfavorable and unusual conditions, whose claims to be treated in the same manner as their fellow workers in the Public Service, living mostly under more favorable conditions, are unanswerable, and should not be denied by any deliberative body which contends that its legislative enactments are based upon a reasonable conception of right, truth and justice.

I conclude by saying that there are many other reasons which could be advanced against the introduction of this bill, the object of which must be clear to everybody. I think that honorable members will agree that the Minister in charge of the bill has not put up a convincing case in its favour. As I have said, this bill has been introduced as a matter of political expediency, and has resulted from the efforts of influential persons to take away the right of certain persons to approach a particular tribunal for the settlement of disputes. I remind honorable members that, if this bill is passed, and it is subsequently found that it inflicts an injustice on a section, of the workers, it will be very difficult to have it repealed. The Minister has stated that the bill and its complementary measure are not to be regarded as party proposals. I appeal to him, and to honorable members generally, that, in fairness to the railway men concerned, they should both be withdrawn, and that the railway men should be extended the measure of justice for which they have been struggling for many years.

Sir LITTLETONGROOM (Darling Downs) ['5.35]. - I ask honorable members to cast their minds back to earlier years, in order to see the. position in which we wore placed when this principle was first introduced. In 1911, an Arbitration (Public Service) Act was passed, and later there was enacted the Arbitration (Public .Service) Act 1920. In 1917, the Commonwealth Railways Act was passed, which provided that the Arbitration (Public Service) Act of -1911 was to apply to the railway service in like manner as it applied to the public servants of the 'Commonwealth. The matter was raised . by the Arbitration (Public Service) Act of 1920, and the question which honorable members were then called upon to decide was whether the definition clause in that act was sufficiently wide to include, and if, in fact, it did include, Commonwealth railway servants. During the progress of the debate on the bill the opinion of the legal advisers of the Government was expressed that railway servants were included in the definition, and that it was intended to include them. At that time, railway employees in the service of the States throughout Australia were excluded from the Commonwealth Arbitration Act, because of an interpretation placed upon the meaning of the Constitution by the High Court. There was, therefore, no power in the Arbitration Act to deal with Federal and State railway employees over the whole of the Commonwealth. A bill was introduced to deal with the Public Service of the Commonwealth, and the remarks which I then made, and which have been quoted by the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford), were directed towards securing what was then really aimed at, the provision of uniform legislation to cover the whole of the Commonwealth public servants throughout the Commonwealth. That principle still applies to-day. In 1911 the definition of " industrial dispute " in the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act included Commonwealth public authorities, and Commonwealth Public servants engaged in an interstate dispute. State railway employees could not be covered, because at that time it was' held that the Commonwealth was not empowered to legislate with respect to them. But it was felt in the absence of uniform industrial legislation that the Commonwealth should have uniform industrial conditions for its own servants. Accordingly an act was passed providing for the appointment of a Public Service Arbitrator. After the introduction of the bill, however, the High Court, in the Engineers' case, decided that State railway employees could come under the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act, and 3ince 1920, the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Court has been dealing effectively with matters affecting State railway workers. It is desirable to have uniformity applied throughout the whole of the railway services, Federal and State, in Australia. These services should be tinder one industrial authority. The Commonwealth by its own legislation has made that pos- sible in regard to its own public servants, and the object of the present bill is to secure uniformity throughout Australia in respect of railway workers. There is nothing which differentiates the Commonwealth railways from the railways of New South Wales, Queensland or Victoria. The western Queensland line, which runs right into the interior, is operated under the same conditions as are the Commonwealth railways. Conditions operating in Western Australia and New South Wales are approximately the same. The trouble at the present time is that in respect of Commonwealth railway employees, two industrial jurisdictions deal with them. When I was Minister for Works and Railways I had trouble in that regard. I found that at one time certain unions would desire to come under a federal award, and at others to be brought under a State tribunal or a wages board, according to the possibility of securing better conditions from either source. Several of the leaders of the unions felt the necessity and the desirability of the adoption of uniform conditions throughout Australia. I am sure the Minister in charge of the bill (Mr. Hughes) knows the inconvenience of having alternative jurisdictions. These bills are merely an expression of the need for much-desired uniformity. In its attempt to achieve uniformity, the Commonwealth legislation covers Federal and State employees, although, in some of the States, for reasons of their own, some of the unions do not desire to participate in this attempt at uniformity. Probably when they find that they, are getting less under the State award than under a Commonwealth award, they may change their attitude. Unless it can be shown that there is gross injustice in Commonwealth awards, we should not endeavour to preserve a tribunal having jurisdiction over Commonwealth railway servants only.

Mr. Beasley.- If the honorable member were a railway worker, would he not try to secure a 44Lhour week under the Public Service Arbitrator instead of the 48-hour week agreed upon by the Arbitration Court?

Sir LITTLETONGROOM.- Naturally, I would approach the tribunal which offered the best conditions. But should not the honorable member seek to establish uniform conditions to operate throughout Australian generally? I am advocating fair and equitable conditions, which, subject to geographical conditions, will have uniform application. Unless we are able to preserve uniformity, conditions operating in respect of railway workers throughout Australia will not be satisfactory. If the railway workers approached the Public Service Arbitrator, and he, after hearing the plaint said, " I will not give you as good conditions as you now get from the other tribunal ", would the honorable member suggest that the railway workers should withdraw from the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator, and approach the Arbitration Court?
Mr. Rosevear.- Surely they should be allowed to sell their labour in the best market.

Sir LITTLETONGROOM.- Such a condition should not be allowed to arise. There should be uniformity in the conditions of railway employees throughout the whole of Australia. If that is not done, rights are given to Commonwealth railway servants that are denied to persons outside the Commonwealth service. To my mind, the Minister has put up a good case, and has been perfectly consistent, because when the original amendment was made in earlier years, different conditions prevailed. This is not in any sense a party question. I am discussing it from the point of view of the desirability of securing uniform conditions in industrial affairs throughout Australia.
Mr. Drakeford.- Would the honorable member favour an amendment to place the railway clerical officers in the same position ?
Sir LITTLETONGROOM.- I shall leave that point until it arises.
Mr. BEASLEY- Then the honorable gentleman does not desire uniformity!
Sir LITTLETONGROOM.- I do so far as it can be achieved. For the reasons I have given, I shall support the bill.

Mr.BARNARD (Bass) [5.45].- I have listened with interest to the introductory speech of the Minister, and the speeches of the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford) and the honorable member for Darling Downs (Sir Little ton Groom). From the history of this legislation, which he traced back as far as 1920, the honorable member for Darling Downs made the deduction that the proposal . which the Government is now putting before .us should be supported in the interests of uniformity. To my mind, that is a deplorably weak argument. Uniformity of hours of work and wages is never likely to be achieved through the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. The workers, having realized this unfortunate fact, are drifting away from the court. This is due largely to the outlook of the judges of the court, whose talk from the Bench about such matters as promotion by senility has undermined the confidence of the workers in the court itself. The gentlemen who have been appointed to the Bench of the Arbitration Court of late years have held views which give the workers little reason for confidence. That they adhere after their elevation to the Bench to the views they previously held has been indicated very clearly in recent awards, and notably in that made to cover Commonwealth railway employees. The whole procedure of the court is causing dissatisfaction, delay and irritation, and is not making for industrial peace. The railway workers have on several occasions obtained awards from the court, but they have only been waiting for the expiry of the award thai has been in operation for the last two or three years so that they could approach the Public Service Arbitrator. They hoped that their claims would be more justly considered by him than they have been by the court. The recent award of the court was so unsatisfactory to the men that they threatened to. cease work unless certain of their grievances were rectified.

Unhappily, the judges of the Arbitration Court often declare that they will will not deal with certain claims submitted to them on the ground that their jurisdiction is limited, and advise the men to approach some other authority or make an appeal to the legislature. Can it be expected that such a procedure will satisfy men suffering under a sense of injustice? The Minister in charge of this bill must be aware of these facts. If he is ignorant of them, he is amazingly indifferent to current events. The Arbitration Court has caused intense dissatisfaction among the workers generally for its failure to deal with the applications made to it for a shorter working week. This dissatisfaction has become acute in the Commonwealth railway service. The excuse advanced on behalf of the court is that such a matter must be dealt with by three judges, and it is asserted that, while so many matters are awaiting the attention of judges who can sit in single jurisdiction, it would not be appropriate for the three judges to withdraw their attention from other matters to deal with the applications for a shorter working week. But surely matters of major importance should have priority of attention from the judges. If necessary, the hearing of a claim affecting, say, a few hundred men should be postponed to deal with claims affecting thousands of men.

The declaration of the Minister that the Government intended to take action to apply to the Commonwealth railway service the long-service leave conditions applicable to the railway workers of Western Australia will be entirely satisfactory to the Commonwealth railway employees. Long-service leave is at present granted in the railway services of Queenslaud, New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania, and it is only proper that it should be granted to Commonwealth railway employees.

I also submit that Commonwealth railway employees should be entitled to the same district allowances as are granted to Commonwealth public servants generally. Why should the Commonwealth railway employees be expected to accept conditions inferior to those enjoyed by employees in other branches of the Commonwealth Service ? Equity demands that "quai consideration shall be given to all.

The honorable member for Maribyruong (Mr. Drakeford) dealt briefly with the important subject of working hours. I desire to deal with the subject at greater length. The Commonwealth railway employees are unfavorably situated in regard to their working hours as compared with the employees of the State railways. According to the Commonwealth Year-Booh. No. 28, which is the latest available, in 1934, there were 93,917 railway employees in Australia, of whom 14,772 were on salary, and 79,145 on wages. The hours worked by the salaried staff may be said to be less than 44 a week ; probably the average would be even less than 40 a week, so that approximately 15,000 of the employees are working less than 40 hours a week. This leaves approximately 79,000 daily-paid workers who work for 44 hours a week or more. Of these, 55,000 are employed on the railway systems of New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia, the respective figures being 33,968, 13,854 and 7,154. The remainder are employed on the railway systems of Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania, the respective figures being 17,450, 5,563, and 1,156. Approximately, 24,000 workers appear, at first sight, to be employed on a 48-hour basis. But from these must be eliminated the artisans and those associated with them. This would probably reduce the number by at least 4,000, leaving not more than 20,000 of the number employed on the State railway services who are on a 44-hour week. That is a very conservative estimate. At page 168 of the Year-Booh, from which I have already quoted, figures will be found showing that at the time the statistics were prepared, about 1,300 persons were employed on Commonwealth railways, of whom 171 were salaried officers working for 44 hours a week or less. At least another 200 of the employees would be artisans or their assistants who would be working 44 hours a week. This leaves about 900 employees on a 48-hour week basis. As business has improved somewhat, these numbers would now be somewhat greater, but the proportion would not be altered. From this it will be seen that a considerable number - in fact, the great majority - of the railway employees in Australia work not more than 44 hours a week. In the Commonwealth railway service, however, the great majority of the daily-paid employees work 48 hours a week.

I am pleased that the Government of Tasmania has decided to apply a 44- hour working week to its employees. The hours of work in the railway services of the various States vary somewhat. Locomotive engine-drivers in the New South Wales service work 88 hours a fortnight. Queensland railway workers enjoy a 44-hour week, and so do those of Western Australia.. When the Tasmanian railway workers are placed on a 44-hour week, as from the 1st July, a considerable measure of uniformity will be achieved, but I cannot see how anything effective to that end is likely to be done by our acceptance of the proposal which the Commonwealth Government is now submitting to us.

The recent awards of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court have shown clearly that its judges are decades behind the times in their outlook, and seem to have no regard for modern developments. The result is that the only employees who approach the court are those who are forced to do so. The railway commissioners are almost compelling employees to approach the court, doubtless because they hold the opinion that it will grant conditions less attractive to the employees, and more attractive to themselves. The judges of the Arbitration Court take into consideration the capacity of an industry to pay. The honorable member for Maribyrnong has pointed out that the Transcontinental railway was built, not with the idea that it would be a payable proposition, but for quite a different reason. In the Arbitration Court the representatives of the commissioners never fail to produce balance-sheets of the year's operations and to stress the losses that have been made. The presiding judge uses those losses as a reason for refusing to reduce the number of hours or to improve the working conditions. This principle has been applied in the Commonwealth court against not only Commonwealth railway employees, but abo the employees of other instrumentalities, with the result that in New South Wales the men are working under a State award which raised their wages and improved their working conditions after the Commonwealth court had refused to concede what they claimed. The Queensland railway men approached the federal court on one occasion and were glad to keep, away from it thereafter. Working under an award of the State Arbitration Court they now enjoy higher wages and better working conditions. The men in Western Australia occupy a similar position. Yet the honorable member for Darling Downs (Sir Littleton Groom) says that this bill makes for uniformity ! It does nothing of the kind. Although some of the railway systems are allegedly working under an award of the federal court, the governments of those States have determined that a working week shall not exceed 44 hours. The last to come into line is the Government of Tasmania. In that State the men enjoy long service leave, and are now to have a shorter working week. These are concessions of the government, not of the Arbitration Court, which says that it can exercise no control over such privileges as long service leave, district allowances, and other privileges which Commonwealth employees are seeking to obtain. If the Commonwealth Government desires to achieve greater uniformity and to have the matter of wages and working conditions determined by the federal court, it must first bring its employees into line with the majority of railway men throughout Australia, by administratively granting those privileges. I am opposed to the bill in the absence of a declaration by the Government as to its intentions in regard to hours and working conditions.

Mr. MAKIN(Hindmarsh) [6.5].- The Minister for Repatriation (Mr. Hughes) left unsaid a lot that he might have said which would have ' enlightened this House as to the reason which actuated the Government in the introduction of this legislation. I invite the Assistant Minister (Mr. Hunter), who, I understand, is to participate actively in this debate, to make good the deficiency.

We have been invited by the Minister to display candour, to disregard the finer technique of this legislation, and to get down to the basic reason for the dissatisfaction of railway men with their present position. I suggest that the right honorable gentleman should explain why this legislation was brought down after the men had submitted memorials to the Public Service Arbitrator for his consideration. If there is any merit in the Government's attitude, why was this action not taken earlier, particularly as the Statute Law Revision Act was passed in 1934? When the railway men seek to exercise a statutory right the Government attempts to defeat their purpose, and to destroy whatever prospect there might be for the rectification of many of the existing anomalies.
Mr. Hughes.- That is wrong.

Mr. MAKIN.- That is clearly what the Government has in mind. It desires to destroy the prospects of these men securing a 44-hour week, and the improvement of their conditions in other respects, which they are confident would be made through the Arbitrator, and which would make a practical contribution toward uniformity in the different services. Following so closely upon the Government's repudiation of its agreement at Geneva by its refusal to consider a proposal for the ratification of the 40-hour working week Convention, the introduction of this legislation, which seeks to prevent the adoption of a 44-hour week is significant. I deliberately repeat the assertion that the purpose of this legislation is to. deprive the Commonwealth railway employees of a. shorter working week, which other sections of the same service enjoy.
Mr. SPEAKER.-Order ! The honorable member is discussing the motives of the Government rather than the bill.
Mr. MAKIN.- Am I not entitled to make such observations as will show to this House the motive which lies behind the introduction of this legislation?
Mr. SPEAKER.-To impute motive, which is unacknowledged, is not in order.

Mr. MAKIN.- I was merely availing myself of the invitation so generously extended by the Minister, to exhibit complete frankness and candour. The Government cannot evade the severe indictment which its action entails. In an attempt to justify what has been done, the Minister said that the Commonwealth railway employees had not taken advantage of the existence of this provision for a period of eighteen years ; he should have said sixteen years. Surely the failure to avail oneself of a right does not deprive one of the claim to that right? The right honorable gentleman's argument is based upon a very weak premise, and is decidedly unconvincing. He has seen fit to make quotations from past records, to indicate my attitude towards earlier legislation. He might well have explained his own attitude. He now finds himself in the position of one who seeks to destroy an instrument of one's own creation. At the least, he might show some regard for consistency, and furnish convincing evidence of the reason for his now adopting an opposite view from that which he held in 1920. I shall await with interest whatever explanation he may think fit to make. In seeking to separate one section of the Commonwealth railway employees from the great body of the Public Service, he will precipitate the condition which he says he desires to avoid. He claims that it is his wish that uniformity of conditions shall prevail. How can he possibly expect that if one section of the railway employees is to be permitted to approach the Public Service Arbitrator, and another section is to be debarred from that right. The right honorable gentleman has advanced no substantial argument which would justify the exercise of such differentiation.

If it is right that the professional and clerical divisions should, be able to approach the Public Service Arbitrator, the other branches of the service who wish to avail themselves of the same medium for the redress of their grievances should surely be placed in a similar position. This has been the law, and it should remain so.
Sitting suspended from 6.15 to 8p.m.

Mr. MAKIN.- The Minister claims that the failure of the union to exercise a right is justification for depriving it of that right. If that were the general rule many injustices would result. People do not always exercise their rights, but it could never be said that their failure to exercise those rights cancelled them. That being so, I feel that the argument advanced by the right honorable gentleman is weak in construction and certainly illogical in its premises. The honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford) this afternoon in an excellent speech in answer to the Minister outlined the vexatious delays that occur in adjustment of grievances of the men in the railway service of the Commonwealth through the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Court. In one instance a case was cited in 1926 and the award was made in 1934. It is rather interesting to note that during that interval the Attorney-General (Mr.

Menzies) took action in the High Court of Australia for the setting aside of the award that was then prevailing, a variation of which was being sought by the Commonwealth railway employees. Unfortunately in recent years workers have been discouraged in seeking redress through the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. The railway employees have not felt happy at the way in which their cases have been dealt with. In fact, the determinations of the court has been responsible for serious resentment and unrest among those affected. Is it surprising then that the organizations representing these men should now seek to take advantage of the statutes by approaching the Public Service Arbitrator, which is their definite right under the law? An unfortunate construction is being placed on the Government's action in bringing down this bill which prevents the employees from pursuing the course proposed. The Government is actually interfering with the process of a judicial tribunal. This bill indicates that it is not prepared to permit its employees to exercise a right that has existed for a considerable period, and which if it had suited the Government would have been taken advantage of by it to the fullest extent.

The Minister desires to secure uniformity of wage conditions and other conditions of employment in the railway services; but while he is seeking to correct what he regards as a lack of uniformity, he will create an anomalous position by causing disparity between public servants. Those associated with the Postal Department as mechanics lend themselves for comparison in this matter. Their wages and conditions of employment are determined by the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator, but the railway men who are qualified in exactly the same way and who are performing the same class of work, because they happen to be employed in the railway service, are to be brought under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. In that respect the Minister will actually bring about a condition which, he says, he desires to correct. The right honorable gentleman, to justify his attitude, said, " Oh, well the railway service is a revenue-producing concern". So is the post office a revenue-producer, and if it is fair to exclude one from the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator, it should be equally fair to exclude the other. No proposal, however, has been made to exclude those in the Postal Department from the Public Service Arbitrator. The Minister must answer to this House for that differentiation, and until such time as he is able to produce a logical and convincing case, proving consistency in the actions of the Government. Furthermore, is it to be laid down as a principle that employees in a revenue-producing department are to be placed in a less favorable .position to that of employees in a non-revenue-earning department? I feel that this House is not warranted in being asked to pass this legislation. The Minister was good enough to advise this House of the principles that I stated in 1920 on legislation on this very question. My principles to-day are absolutely in agreement with those which I espoused in 1920. The right honorable gentleman at that time introduced legislation extending arbitration to the whole of the Commonwealth Public Service, and, if he were seeking now to bring all of the Public Service under the same conditions as those obtaining in outside employment, I could recognize the logic of his case, and so could all of those who speak in the same way as myself. However, he only seeks to employ this measure against one portion of the Public Service, and does not intend it to be of general application. The Government should not seek to 'segregate men in the Public Service. The conditions laid down should be uniformly consistent with those in private employment under a remodelled and uniform arbitration system. If the honorable gentleman presented legislation to this House to embrace the whole of the Public Service, I should be prepared to support it in accordance with my earlier declarations. . The present attitude of the Minister is in striking contrast to his attitude in 1920. He is not justified in pursuing a course which is nothing less than class distinction. He is to give to the professional class the advantage of securing an award of the Public Service Arbitrator, but in the case of the ordinary daily or weekly-paid workers he insists that their claims be dealt with by the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. The Minister is seeking to make a distinction between the professional class of officer and railway men.
Mr. Hughes.- That is not so.
Mr. MAKIN.- It is so.
Mr. Hughes.- It is a different class of work.

Mr. MAKIN.- I am expressing a fact which the denials of the Minister cannot disturb. Those engaged as daily-paid men engaged in the railway workshops and in . the running of the railways, and those who are labourers and all other daily-paid workers within the railway service are to be excluded from the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator.
Mr. Hughes.- They excluded themselves.
Mr. MAKIN.- How did they exclude themselves ?
Mr. Hughes.- They would not approach the Arbitrator.

Mr. MAKIN.-The men have five memorials before the Arbitrator now. The right honorable gentleman cannot get away with that. He knows that memorials have been presented to the Arbitrator, and that this bill is an effort by the Government to prevent the men engaged in the railway service from obtaining uniformity. For the right honorable gentleman to try to persuade this House to believe that the railway men have not the right to approach the. Arbitrator is wrong. They have exercised their right, and the Government is now trying to deprive them of it. The Government is taking a very serious step in interfering with the process of the law and in imposing retrospective conditions in the statute - a practice which is unjust and inequitable. The daily-paid workers employed by the Commonwealth Railways Department have every reason to complain bitterly of the action of the Government. I agree with the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford)., who so ably led the debate from this side of the House, that the mon should be conceded the right to approach the Public Service Arbitrator, when they have by ballot expressed their wish to do so, and have already taken steps to that end. If this bill is. passed, much discontent will be occasioned throughout the service, and the way will be opened for the creation of many anomalies. For instance, Commonwealth railway workers employed on the Darwin section of the North-South line will be working 44 hours a week, while those employed on the East-West line will be working 48 hours a week. Surely the Minister does not fully appreciate the difficulties which will be created by the passing of this legislation ! I have heard the Minister say that he would do nothing to prevent the workers from securing redress of their grievances through properly-appointed tribunals ; yet now he is sponsoring a measure designed to prevent the employees of the Commonwealth itself from gaining access to a tribunal especially created for Commonwealth, employees. That tribunal it is considered can ensure uniform conditions throughout the Public Service. Even if the men are forced to go before the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, it will be impossible to secure, through that tribunal, uniform working conditions on all the railways throughout the Commonwealth, because Queensland and Western Australia do not come under the jurisdiction of that court. The Minister has not presented one sound reason why we should accept his invitation to abandon, the legislation for which he himself wasresponsible in 1920. I hope that the Government will reconsider its decision, and withdraw this bill, which possesses no merit, and is not even a step in thedirection of uniformity. On the contrary,, it will create fresh anomalies, and will work injury to those concerned. On behalf of all the organizations involved,, particularly the Australian Workers. Union, and the engineering organizations, to which most of those affected belong,. 1 protest with all the vehemence at my disposal against this measure.

Mr. MCBRIDE(Grey) [8.20].- I have a particular interest in the bill now before the House, not only because of the principle involved, but also because many of the men who will be affected by thismeasure are resident in the electoratewhich I represent. It is, therefore, my duty, when considering this proposed legislation, to assess, as well as I can,. its probable effect upon the men concerned. It must be rather disturbing to many of us, who have for' years supported the principle of arbitration, to hear the astounding accusations that have been made against the Federal Arbitration Court in its dealings with Commonwealth railway workers. In the past, while I have always been a staunch supporter of arbitration, I confess that I entertained doubts as to how the workers would react when the economic tide turned, and conditions became such that the arbitration courts, Federal and State, would be compelled to stop granting further concessions, and to begin reducing wages and varying conditions to the detriment of employees. I desire now to say how much I appreciate the action of the workers throughout Australia in accept ing so loyally the reductions made from time to time by various arbitration tribunals during the time of the depression through which Australia has passed. It seems to me that, as the workers accepted those sacrifices in so fine a spirit, they have now a right, when times have improved, to expect a restoration of the benefits that were taken from them. It is with that idea in mind that I propose to discuss this measure.

It is admitted that, until the award of 1932, the men, while perhaps not always satisfied, were at least prepared to accept the decisions of the court. It has been stated that they did not, on all occasions, approach the court, but in 1.927 they did so, and accepted the decision of the judge. In 1932, of course, it was the Railways Commissioner who applied to the court, and it is against the award issued in response to that application that the men are now taking such strong exception. As honorable members will recall, when that award flame out there was a suggestion by some of the men that they should refuse to accept it. As a matter of fact, there was a probability of a strike on the Commonwealth railways. As the representative of the men in this Parliament, I was asked by their officials, while I was in Port Augusta, to discuss the position with them. I agreed to do so, and told them that, as a supporter of arbitration, I could not countenance direct action ; that, as they had appealed to the court on other occasions and accepted its awards, so they must accept the award of the court on this occasion.. I said then, however, as I say now, that while there was an obligation upon the men to observe the award, there was also an obligation upon the Commissioner to make conditions of employment as satisfactory as possible. I pointed out that, although the Government could not countenance any attempt to flout the award of the court, there still remained matters within the control of the Commissioner in regard to which representations might be made to him. I suggested that the men should approach the Commissioner in regard to rent3 for the cottages they occupied. The rents were probably assessed on the cost of construction, the cottages having been built with money borrowed at 5 per cent, or 6 per cent. As the result of conversion operations, the rate of interest had in the meantime been reduced, and it was only reasonable that the benefit of that reduction should be passed on to the men. I do not suggest that anything I had to say to the men on that occasion very greatly influenced them, or that the representations which I made subsequently to the Commissioner swayed him to any great extent. I merely point out that, when. the men applied to the Commissioner, he did make some very definite concessions. He reduced rents by 10 per cent., and gave a discount of 5 per cent, on all goods purchased from Government stores, thus contributing considerably to the amelioration of the hardships imposed by the award of the court. I recognize that the Arbitration Court, when considering applications made to it, does, in fact, take into account the economic position of the industry concerned, or, in the case of the Public Service, the economic position of the country. That, I know, has been denied, but the action of the Arbitration Court during the period of the depression fully proves that such is the case.

I realize that the position of the men employed on the Commonwealth railways is different from that of those employed by private enterprise. As was stated by the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford), it was never hoped, when the Commonwealth railways were constructed, that they would be a paying proposition. It was constructed mainly to give means of communication to Western Australia, when it joined the federation, and it was also regarded as valuable for defence purposes. Therefore, the court could not base its award on the earnings or losses on that line. I was surprised to hear the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford) say that the losses on the various railway systems in Australia are due to low freight charges. It would be interesting to compare the rates in Australia with those in other countries. I point out that the freight rates on Australian railways are from two to three times as high as those in Canada and the United States of America. The Arbitration Court has taken the economic conditions of the country into consideration, and from time to time has restored benefits taken away in times of stress. The Full Court altered the basis of assessing the basic wage in April, 1934, and restored the amount by which the wage was reduced under the financial emergency legislation. Automatic increases of wages have taken place on account of increases of the cost of living. In Kalgoorlie, prior to the award made by His Honour Judge Drake-Brockman, the men were receiving l2s. 6d. a day less 10 per cent., which made the actual wage11s. 3d. a day, but now the rateis 13s. 8d. a day.
Mr. Drakeford.-Almost entirely due to the excessive cost of house rent.
Mr. McBRIDE.- I said that it was due to the increase of the cost of living, of which house rent is an important part. This shows that the court takes cognizance of economic conditions.
Mr. SPEAKER.-The merits or otherwise of judgments of the court may not be discussed.

Mr. McBRIDE.- I merely desire to show that, in good times, the court grants increased rates of pay to the employees. The district allowance, which has been agreed to by the Government, will be secured to the employees in the future. Long service leave has been granted to the men by the present Government. This is not a matter for determination by the Arbitration Court or the Public Service Arbitrator. It is provided for under the
Public Service Act, and the Government is consistent in agreeing to allow the employees to retain this concession.

It seems to me that the employees wish to appeal to the Public Service Arbitrator only on the matter of the 44hour week. The question of the hours of work has always been one for determination by the tribunals, and the Government, on this occasion refuses to depart from the usual practice, and suggests that the men should make application to the Arbitration Court. The representatives of the employees claim that the court has already refused an application for a 44-hour week. I point out that many applications made from time to time on behalf of the employees' in various industries have been unsuccessful, but the court has eventually acceded to this request when it has found that an industry can afford to grant it. As recently as June last, the court awarded a 44-hour week to the coachbuilders, carpenters, joiners, plumbers and gas-fitters employed on the Commonwealth railways. Prior to that, the metal trade workers on those railways had enjoyed a 44-hour week for some time. I think it may be said that, when the court deems it advisable to do so, and when the general body of workers in Australia have been granted a 44-hour week, it will give this boon to all sections of employees of the Commonwealth railways. I believe that that is the objective of all governments. The demands of civilisation require the granting of improved conditions, more leisure, and greater comforts for the workers generally, and I have always said that, as soon as it is possible to grant it, all sections in Australia should be awarded a 44-hour week. Whilst I believe that governments should be ideal employers, they would not be justified in giving their employees conditions out of all relation to those applying to the general body of the workers throughout Australia. The Government and the Commissioner of Railways have shown that, apart from wages and hours of employment, they are prepared to grant concessions to railway employees. The district allowance is not enjoyed by workers in private employment, but I regard it as a reasonable concession.

The conditions under which Commonwealth railway employees live could be materially improved. In some instances, they occupy hovels; I use the word advisedly. It would be disgraceful for any private employer to ask his men to live in such dwellings, and it is all the more discreditable to a government whose employees are associated with a permanent undertaking such as a railway system. The housing conditions should be improved. I entirely agree with the statement that Commonwealth railway employees are peculiarly situated. State railway employees are moved from time to time to districts which give them variety in regard to climate, working and living conditions, but Commonwealth railway employees are confined to semi-arid districts. Apart from the trying climatic conditions under which they live, their children suffer lack of opportunities. On the South Australian railways, somewhat similar climatic conditions obtain on the Peterborough-Cockburn line, but the employees in that locality can be transferred to Adelaide or Mount Gambier, where the living conditions are more pleasant, and their children have greater opportunities. We have every right to expect the Government to exercise leniency in the conditions and privileges granted to these men. I hope the question of housing in particular will be considered very seriously, because I believe that the conditions under which the men live in some instances are an absolute disgrace. I think that the Government has gone a long way to. assure the men that it is not definitely out to harm them, but, on the contrary, 13 out to look after their welfare. The very fact that this bill has been introduced by the right honorable member for North Sydney, who has spent a lifetime in advocating the adoption of the system of arbitration in Australia, is at least some assurance that nothing will be done to jeopardize their interests.

Mr.BLACKBURN (Bourke) [8.46].- I desire to deal with two points as briefly as possible. The Minister (Mr. Hughes) accused the Locomotive Engine-men's Union of inconsistency in that, having first desired to go to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, it now desires to go to the Public Service Arbitrator. Assuming that the right honorable member's contention is correct, the Government itself has been guilty of inconsistency, because it ha3 passed a measure intended to confine government employees to the Public Service Arbitrator only. I know that the Minister says that that was done accidentally and unintentionally; the fact is that it has been done, and I cannot believe that it was done accidentally or inadvertently. The position was that the High Court in 1933 decided that the Locomotive Enginemen's Union, being a union registered in the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, could approach that court. The Commonwealth Railways Commissioner's answer to that, which was that section 11 of the Arbitration (Public Service) Act prevented such a course being adopted, was overruled. Mr. Justice Starke, among other judges, examined that section, and pointed out that it did not prevent the Locomotive Engine-men's Union from going to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court with a two-State dispute, under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act: that before the amendment of the Arbitration (Public Service) Act it could go to the Arbitration Court in either of two ways - it could create a two-State dispute and go to it by right of the federal power to deal with interstate disputes, or it could exercise its special privilege to do so under the Arbitration (Public Service) Act as a union of government employees. Section 11 sub-section 1 of the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1920 reads-

Notwithstanding anything contained in the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1911, an organization of employees in the Public Service shall not 'be entitled to submit to the Court under that act any claim relating to the salaries, wages, rates of pay, or terms or conditions of service or employment of members of the organization.

Mr. JusticeStarke said in his judgment that only took away the unions' right to approach the court without a twoState dispute. The words "under thaiact", had that effect. What did the Commonwealth Government do? It did what the Minister now says was done inadvertently; it introduced during the following year a Statute Law Revision Bill, to which nobody's attention was drawn, the fourth schedule of which amended section 11 of the Arbitration

Public Service Act by deleting the words " under that act which Mr. Justice Starke had regarded as vitally important aud as securing to the union the right m a two-State dispute to approach the court. Thus, before the bill now under consideration was introduced, it was the desire of the Commonwealth Government to compel its railway employees to go to the Public Service Arbitrator only. It therefore cannot complain of the union's inconsistency. It has showed inconsistency itself by passing an act to compel persons to go to the Public Service Arbitrator, and now by trying to compel them to go to the Arbitration Court.

It is always considered that legislation ought not be passed which takes away from persons a right which has already accrued to them. In this case, the union is actually before the Public Service Arbitrator. It is not merely contemplating going before him ; the Arbitrator is at present hearing the case, and this bill will have the effect of preventing the Arbitrator from proceeding any further with the hearing of the case.
Mr.Beasley. - That makes the bill seem very suspicious.

Mr. BLACKBURN.-It does not preserve existing rights and provide that no further proceeding shall be commenced before the Public Service. Arbitrator ; it takes away the jurisdiction of the Arbitrator now. The Minister will remember that on a previous occasion when he was very anxious to prevent a single judge of the Arbitration Court from dealing with the question of standard hours, he introduced an amendment of the Arbitration Act providing that standard hours could not be altered except by a court consisting of three judges; but he also inserted a clause which provided that the proposed amendment should not affect any proceedings already commenced. That was done in accordance with a well-recognized principle. But the bill now under consideration proposes to take away from the Locomotive Enginemen's Union and its members a right which has already accrued to them. They have commenced proceedings before the Public Service Arbitrator, and the right to continue them should be preserved.

Mr.HOLLOWAY (Melbourne Ports) [8.52]. - I join with the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford) in protesting against the introduction of this bill. 1 remind the Minister (Mr. Hughes) that he is not the only one who stands for uniformity of industrial laws and conditions. I differ from the right honorable gentleman, however, in his interpretation of uniformity. The real thing that matters to the men engaged in industry is uniformity in working conditions, rates of pay and hours of labour. It is not a question of uniformity on paper or uniformity of the law, but rather one of having uniform working conditions, which the right honorable member and other in the early days of arbitration in Australia set out to achieve. ' They said, " If you have not uniform conditions all over the country in similar industries, there must be discontent among the employees, and you cannot have fair competition between employers." They did not mean uniformity on paper alone.
Mr.Hughes. - We tried to get uniformity on paper too.

Mr. HOLLOWAY,-It is of no use to have uniformity on paper only; the real thing is to achieve uniformity in conditions of work, pay and hours of labour. When we examine this matter from that point of view, we find that the brief which the right honorable gentleman holds now on behalf of the Government is a very poor one. In its treatment of Commonwealth railway servants, the Commonwealth Government has shown itself to be the worst employer in this country. Despite what, the Minister in his advocacy of uniformity has said, it is a strange fact that there is a great lack of uniformity throughout the Commonwealth railway service. No uniformity of conditions exists in this service as the result of the working of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. In 1927. Judge Beeby inquired into the working of the northern end of the North-South railway, and awarded the men certain wages and conditions and a working week of 44 hours. Within a few months, Judge Drake-Brockman inquired into the working of the men engaged on, the southern end of the line, from Alice Springs to Quorn, and refused to award them conditions similar to those enjoyed by those engaged on the northern end of the line. This lack of uniformity must obviously be responsible for the internal discontent among the men which it is desired to eliminate. The more we examine the attitude of this Government towards its railway servants, whether it be the Commissioner or his staff, the more we are convinced of the justification for the protest which railway men make to-day. Railway men proceeding on long service leave from Tasmania. Queensland, or Western Australia, for instance, can travel all over Australia on a free pass. No State raises objection to that procedure ; but Commonwealth employees are not granted a free pass on the same basis because they are not entitled to long-service leave, and the Commonwealth will not allow State employees to travel over its lines on a free pass.
Mr. Hughes.- The Commonwealth railway employees get a free pass.

Mr. HOLLOWAY.- But they do not get long-service leave. Compared with the servants of the State railways, Commonwealth railway employees are treated very shabbily. There is no getting away from that, and I can assure honorable members that I derive no pleasure in having to make such an admission. I have travelled over all of the railways in Australia, and have observed the conditions under which the men are employed. I have studied the conditions which operate on the northern' and southern end of the North-South line and the Transcontinental line, and I have said here and in other places that the conditions under which the men _ are engaged on those lines are much worsethan those operating in any of the States of Australia. The right honorable member for North Sydney knows that the men engaged on the Commonwealth railway system are isolated from the more populous centres of Australia, and are frequently located in places where the climatic conditions leave much to be desired. Because of the loss of social amenities, they should be given improved conditions. Some of the things which I witnessed on the North-South line made me ashamed of being a member of this Parliament. I have seen most of the working agreements that exist in other countries of the world, with regard to not only railway services, but also other services, and I have never come across such bad conditions as operate on the northern end of the North-South line. I was informed that the men engaged there, who are unfortunate enough to suffer injury during working hours, have to pay their own travelling expenses to a doctor, or to a place where they can obtain first-aid treatment. I asked one of the men whether that was true, and I was informed that in such cases a man had to pay 50 per cent, of the usual fare. I have never come across similar conditions in any part of the world. The poorest private employer would take an injured employee to hospital, and would not expect him to bear the cost of conveyance. I derive no pleasure in exposing things of this kind. All over Australia we should have similar minimum conditions for railway employees whether they operate under a State or Federal award, and special consideration is given when the conditions are unusual. At the present time, four States in the Commonwealth are employing railway men on a 44-hour week. The men employed on the Adelaide to Port Augusta railway and the Commonwealth railway employees on the Transcontinental line and also the line from Quorn to Alice Springs work 48 hours a week. It is hardly likely that contentment will rule in a service where men have to work four hours a week longer for one employer than men doing the 3ame kind of job have to work for another employer. The introduction of the Commonwealth industrial arbitration system was justified years ago partly on the ground that it would enable uniform conditions to be applied to similar industries throughout the country. Unfortunately that hope has not been realized. The effort to apply a common rule has failed. In the circumstances it is not surprising that men become tired of using orthodox means to rectify their grievances. It is highly regrettable, also, that a Government which professes to favour the adoption of constitutional methods for the settlement of industrial disputes, should reward its own employees who adopt that procedure by withdrawing from them a right which they have possessed for sixteen years. About half the men engaged in our railway works are technicians or artisans who are able to obtain awards irrespective of the views of the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner. I refer, of course, to the blacksmiths, boiler-makers, carpenters, fitters, turners, upholsterers and other artisans who work on our railways. If States such as Western Australia, Tasmania and Queensland can afford to give their railway employees a 44-hour week, the Commonwealth should concede similar working hours to its railway employees. I can see no reason whatever for withdrawing from the Commonwealth railway employees the right to approach the Public Service Arbitrator. The mere fact that they have not done so during the last sixteen years is no justification for withdrawing from them the right to do so now. It is strange that on their first endeavour to obtain an award from the Public . Service Arbitrator, the Government should have introduced, a.measure of this description. Probably if the railway employees had taken similar action ten years ago they may have found themselves in the same position. The railway employees have approached the Public Service Arbitrator, not simply because they consider his tribunal better than the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, but mainly because of the thoroughly unsatisfactory experience they have had in the court in the last eight or nine years. Three years ago the Australian Workers Union and the Commonwealth railway employees submitted a claim to Judge Drake-Brockman which was resisted by the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner. The Judge at that time made an award which obviously was ultra vires the Arbitration Act, but when this was pointed out to him he intimated that he did not intend to be bound by the views of other people. It was well known to everybody at that time that the right of a single Judge to reduce the basic wage or either increase or decrease working hours, had been withdrawn; but Judge Drake-Brockman was not worried by a consideration of that kind. When the subject was discussed subsequently in this House the then Attorney-General, now Sir John Latham, had to admit that he had a bad case. He moved the High Court, however,, to inquire into the whole position with the result that our discussion of the subject was stifled on the ground that the matter was sub judice. During the whole time that the court was considering the subject the railway employees had withheld from them a certain proportion of their wages. It is true that, eventually, this money was paid to them, but why should they have been denied the use of it for so long? Undoubtedly it is the experience which the railway men have had with Judge Drake-Brockman in the Arbitration Court that has caused them to seek the redress of their grievances by another tribunal. The Government cannot expect us to accept the argument that this proposal is being submitted to Parliament in the interests of uniformity, for uniformity has not been achieved during the long years that the workers have been looking to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court to redress their wrongs. I am not concerned about the argument that a similar tribunal should be provided for all Commonwealth employees, clerical and otherwise. It is far more important that similar classes of work should be under the jurisdiction of particular tribunals. The Minister has signally failed to justify our acceptance of these cognate bills in the interests of uniformity. As the railway workers have been denied justice in the Arbitration Court, they are fully entitled to seek it from the Public Service Arbitrator.

Mr. BLAIN(Northern .Territory, [9.9]. - I rise to protest against the monotonous use of the catch cry "uniformity, uniformity, uniformity ", and I am amazed that the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) should have joined in the chorus. He could not of course be aware of the real conditions that obtain on the roof of Australia, at Darwin, and also in Central Australia, because he, like most other people, including Judge Drake-Brockman himself, visited the Northern Territory in the winter time. Those who desire to obtain a real understanding of the humidity, general discomfort and diversity of climate in the Northern Territory, and particularly at Darwin, should do their touring there in the summer time. I am not au fait with the conditions of all the railway workers throughout Australia, and so am at a disadvantage in discussing this subject, compared with the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford) ; but I propose to draw on my own personal experience to show how illogical it would be to apply uniform conditions throughout Australia. I listened with interest and appreciation to the logical speech which the honorable member for Maribyrnong delivered; but 1 am not so much concerned, at the moment, whether the railway workers approach the Public Service Arbitrator or the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, as with the injustice of the suggestion that uniform working conditions should be applied even to all railway workers. I assume that the Commonwealth railway employees have good reason for departing from their practice of the last eighteen years by approaching the Public Service Arbitrator in preference to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. My main purpose in speaking to the bill is to indicate clearly to honorable members that the much more strenuous working conditions in the Northern Territory entitle the workers there to shorter working hours than those enjoyed by workers in the southern parts of Australia. I speak now with an advantage over many honorable members on both sides of the House, because I have myself worked in railway cuttings, and with these hands have used, not a pen as a clerical worker, but a No. 5 shovel, as a navvy on the Narrogin railway in Western Australia. J. well remember old Paddy Donovan saying to me: " Now laddie, get down to it. There's muck waiting for you and a good No. 5 shovel ; see that you bury it to the maker's name." If some honorable gentlemen of this House had been with me then in the hottest days of the summer, they would not now be speaking so glibly about the desirability of uniform working conditions. The humid climate of the far north is very severe and entitles the workers there to special consideration. To illustrate the effect of these conditions, I shall refer to another personal experience. On one occasion I sent to Rockhampton for an axeman with whom I had worked at Bowen years before. I wanted him to come to the Katherine in the Northern Territory. He agreed to come, and I met him at Camooweal. When I knew this man first he was able to bury a 4^-lb. Kelly axe right up to the eye in green timber. But in the Northern Territory he could not do so, and he was very distressed. He said to me, after he had been working with me for awhile : " I am not going to take £6 10s. a week for the work I am doing here. I cannot do the work here that I did even in Bowen ". I said to time: "Do not be. foolish. Men cannot be expected to work here on hard physical toil like they do in other less severe climates ". I tried to get him to realize that conditions in the Northern Territory were very different from those of Bowen and-- southern Queensland, but he would not listen to me. He threw lip his job, and went away into Western Australia kangaroo shooting. He was too sensitive to work with me, because he could not do the same amount of work in the same time as he was accustomed to do when I first knew him and worked with him. Honorable members must delete the word "uniformity " from their vocabulary when they talk about industrial operations on the roof of Australia at Darwin, and even in Central Australia.
Mr. Drakeford.- Should a man at Alice Springs work longer hours than a man at Darwin?
Mr. BLAIN.-Obviously. The further north one goes, the less capable is one of doing the work. If the honorable member has done any manual labour he has no need to ask me that question.
Mr. Drakeford.- The nearer one is to the equator, the less one should work?
Mr. BLAIN.-Obviously.
Mr. Drakeford.- Then the men at Alice Springs should work less than those at Quorn?
Mr. BLAIN.- Of course they should.
Mr. Drakeford.- But they do not.

Mr. BLAIN.- That is the point up to which I am working. It furnishes n reason for my objection to uniformity, which is not fair to the men who have to work under grim conditions. The further north one goes, the greater is the grimness. Judge Drake-Brockman visited Darwin in the winter, not in the summer, and, therefore, could not form a correct opinion, any more than could the honorable member for Melbourne Ports.

I agree with the remarks of the honorable member for Grey (Mr. McBride), in regard to the housing conditions of the men who are employed from Charlotte Waters northward. But although he stressed the point, he did not say sufficient to indicate adequately how little is done, not only from Quorn northward, but also from Birdum to Darwin, a distance of 320 miles. Ever since I became a member of this House I have argued that where a government officer is stationed in a small community, the housing conditions should be such that he can have his womenfolk with him from the "fall of the flag". On many of the cattle stations run by private enterprise in the Northern Territory, little or no effort is made to provide accommodation for womenfolk. A young man who went to Darwin on the last boat asked me if I could find him a job. I said, " Why go there ?" and he replied, "I am just in from Wave Hill. I am engaged tq be married, and cannot take a wife out there ". The reason was that private enterprise had made little or no provision for the housing of womenfolk. I admit that it is a problem, but it is the duty, of this , Parliament to lead the way in making the housing and other conditions . suitable for womenfolk, so that the issue, may . be forced with private enterprise; . < ,

The carpenters employed by the Railways Department at Darwin receive £6 5s. 7d. a week, whereas those who are employed by the Works Department are paid £6 0s. 2d. Yet the two departments often work in conjunction. As a matter of fact, when the carpenters employed by the Railways Department have work to do for which they have not the necessary tools - saws, benches, &c. - they- make use of the facilities provided by the Works Department. Thus, there is the spectacle of carpenters working side by side at the same bench, in the same climate, but at different rates of wages. I ask the Minister to remove this anomaly for this is where uniformity should be applied. In all other respects it should find no place in our industrial awards.

Mr. CURTIN(Fremantle) [9.20].- This Parliament, sixteen years ago, passed an amending act which, in effect, gave to the employees of the Commonwealth Railways the right to approach by memorial the Public Service Arbitrator. The bills submitted to us. to-day ^ have for their purpose the cancellation in substance of the act then, passed. That is to say, this Parliament is asked to reverse a procedure which has operated for more than a decade and a half. But that is not the worst feature. It is asked to do this in such a way that the operation will have retrospective effect, in that those unions which felt that they should exercise a right given to them by the law had already taken very much more than the initial steps to bring their representations before the lawfully appointed tribunal. As the law stood at the end of last year, the Public Service Arbitrator was perfectly competent to hear the memorial that had been submitted to -him by the unions, which felt that they ought to take that course, and, under the statutes of this Parliament, had every right to approach him. They felt that they ought to approach him because they assumed that they were members of the Commonwealth Public Service.
Mr. Hughes.- To whom does the honorable member refer when he uses the expression " they " ?
Mr. CURTIN.- The Australian Workers Union, the locomotive enginemen, and the boilermakers. I cite those as representative bodies.
Mr. Hughes.- They did not file a memorial at that time.
Mr. Drakeford.- It was filed before this legislation was introduced.

Mr. CURTIN.-The right honorable gentleman must know that the proceedings in respect of the memorial had proceeded so far that a compulsory conference was held on the 31st January of this year. Such a conference could not have been summoned until the memorial had been submitted in proper form, and rejoinders had been made to it. It is apparent, therefore, that the memorial must have been presented approximately at the end of last year to permit of a compulsory conference being summoned as early as the 31st January of this year. At that date, when the initial proceedings for this adjudication were in judicial process, there was no suggestion that this Parliament should be asked to annul a law which wa3 then in function. 1 submit that, by the bill which we are now considering, this Government is interfering with the lawful functioning of the arbitrational procedure which, having been set in motion, the unions believed ought not to be interfered with as the result of political action or political pressure. It would be disastrous if, during' the proceedings incidental to any claim for an award, there should be action by this Parliament depriving either party of the rights which the law gave to it at the time when the proceedings were initiated. That seems to me the outstanding fault of the legislation which the right honorable gentleman has brought down to-day. It must be obvious to the Parliament that this action is being taken for reasons which he has not stated. He said, in effect, this afternoon : What substantial injustice will be done to the men if they are permitted to go to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration? With that interrogation, he disposed of the whole matter. I put to him this question: What substantial injustice will be done to the Government if the men are permitted to continue the proceedings they have initiated before the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator? Does the Government say that the Public Service Arbitrator will not impartially adjudicate upon the issues that have been submitted to him? Does it ask us to believe that it can entrust postal servants, but not railway employees, to his care? Does the right honorable gentleman contend that it is perfectly proper for the stationmaster at Cook to approach the Arbitrator, but not for the locomotive engine-driver who takes the train from Port Augusta to Cook, to do so? Upon what reasonable premises does he justify the discrimination which this legislation undoubtedly establishes between two employees of the same employer? He asks for simplicity, for definiteness, and for uniformity - if I may use a word about which the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Blain) has discoursed so illuminatingly I say to him that there never has been uniformity in respect of arbitrational awards, and that, at this stage, any approximation to uniformity in a service so diverse as that of the railway systems of Australia, is inconceivable.' As a matter of fact the States of Queensland and Western Australia have not, within recent years, appeared before the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. For the most part, that court has dealt only with the railwayemployees of the States of Victoria,. South Australia, and Tasmania. From his vast experience, .the right honorable gentleman will, I think, agree that the general conditions under which the railway men of Victoria now work, and will continue to work for a decade, are not at all reconcilable with those under which the railway men in the employ of the Commonwealth will work. The railway from Quorn to Alice Springs, and that from Port Augusta to Kalgoorlie, pass through practically empty country. The conditions are anything but genial, and there is no variation of the climate. The honorable gentleman says, " I have taken cognizance of that." If I say to him that his Government has taken cognizance of it belatedly, I am not implying that any censure rests upon him. This is the. first opportunity which he has had to act in this matter. I believe that the men will thank him for the fact that long-service leave, which has hitherto been denied to them, is about to be granted .to them.-. But I put it to him that that does npt. make the conditions even approximate to the general conditions under which the railway men of Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania work, they being the men who customarily appear before the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, for the reason that long-service leave is already enjoyed by the great majority of the railway employees of Australia. That is introduced because it is regarded as a reasonable surcease from the monotony of employment, and, in the case of locomotive enginemen, from employment which, in its very nature, imposes a considerable strain. In granting long-service leave, the right honorable gentleman does not give to the Commonwealth railway employees anything which will compensate them for the conditions under which they have to work. He knows that, in Victoria and Western Australia, it is customary to transfer men from semiarid regions to a more congenial station, after they have been stationed in them for some period of years. That certainly is the case in Western Australia, the State of which I have the greatest' knowledge. Railway employees who have been stationed at Mullewa or Meekathara may be transferred to Bunbury, Fremantle, Albany, or Geraldton. In Victoria, those who have been stationed for some time in the Mallee may be transferred to the south-western district, or to some other more salubrious and congenial district, where their wives and families may enjoy some of the compensating virtues which nature itself furnishes. But for the employees on the North-South line ' and -the Transcontinental line, the Commonwealth Government has no such resources. ' It can transfer a man from Zanthus; but where to? To a region precisely identical to Zanthus where the north winds still blow and the dust penetrates and where all the adverse conditions that can be .imagined exist, such as loneliness for' themselves, their wives and their families, and absolute lack of recreational' facilities or entertainment for their leisure hours. They are isolated from the general social life of this Commonwealth. No compensation can be given to them in respect of that deprivation except by the fact that they can earn more money in a less period of time than would be the case anywhere else. I suggest to the right honorable gentleman that their hours could be reduced. The Government has agreed to allow long service leave, which we welcome, and to allow the tribunal whichever it be for the time being to decide the question of district allowances. Having yielded those two points which were adamantly opposed by the Commissioner in previous proceedings, a considerable step forward has been made. I now put it to the Minister that 44 hours- should be the maximum working week, having regard to the inhospitable conditions under which the men have to work and the other conditions which. I will not weary the House by repeating, but all of which make reductions of the hours of labour reasonable. Without some advantage of hours of labour and rates of pay, but for the existence of unemployment it would be extremely difficult to get labour to man these railways which form one of the essential services of the Australian people.

In substance the question the Minister put to us to reply to was, " What substantial injustice would be done to the men to deprive them of the right to go to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator ? " This I answer by stating that the right honorable gentleman has to satisfy, this House that some injustice will be done to the Government in the efficiency of the service by permitting the men to have the option which the law has hitherto given to them. On the question of uniformity I have set out to establish that there is no general approximation between the conditions of the railway men in the Commonwealth service and the men in the State services. I have travelled the Transcontinental line more often than for reasons of comfort I would have wished. To be a passenger is itself unpleasant, but to have to work on the service is worse. That is one aspect of the case, but an even more important aspect is that the great bulk of the Commonwealth servants who are engaged in industrial work, that is to say, men who are artisans, mechanics and labourers engaged in the telephone, telegraph, and postal services are to be allowed to remain under the jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator. A postman who is engaged in the service of this Commonwealth at a place like Cook or Alice Springs has more in common with the railway employee at Cook or Alice Springs than he has with a man of his own occupation 1,000 miles away.
