Fo'r the purpose of this legislation railway men who have to live at Cook are like the postal officials who have to live there, and it is far safer, on the basis of uniformity, to give them one arbitrator than it is to put the whole of the postal services of Australia under the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator and to attempt to put the whole of the Commonwealth railway employees under the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. I am not seeking to determine which of these tribunals they should have access to, but his ] Parliament has permitted the railway men to hare a choice as to where they will go. In the past they have been allowed access to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator, or to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration.

I ask Parliament to look back on the history of this matter. Is it not true that invariably awards which have been made for these employees have been respected and honoured? Have we any reason to fear that because the men engaged in the railway service now desire, like men engaged in the postal service, to apply to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator they will be less loyal to the provisions of such award as may be made than they have been in the past? What danger is there if the Arbitrator makes an award as between the Commissioner for Railways for the Commonwealth and the employees engaged on the two Commonwealth railways? I ask honorable gentlemen opposite to give to me some substantial reasons for any apprehensions they may entertain that it would be detrimental either to efficiency or to equity and good conscience to give these men the rights that they seek. I reasonably surmise that these bills have been brought down because customarily the employees of the Commonwealth who go to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator believe that they have a reasonable expectation of getting a 44-hour week,_ and because the railway employees of the Commonwealth services probably entertain the same hope. The Arbitration Court which does not deal with railway employees in these special regions, but with employees in the more settled cities of Australia, and which probably has no knowledge of the great diversity of conditions and relative severity of hardship of employees in the Commonwealth railway service against those engaged in the State railway services, probably feels that it would be unwise for it to deal with the standard hours other than in the way that has generally been the case. I remind the Minister that it takes three judges of the Arbitration Court to deal with any question of hours. I further put it to him that when a court is dealing with all classes of employees - employees of pri vate enterprise as well as those engaged in public instrumentalities - that come before it, at least the motives and reasons that animate it in dealing with hours can be understood when it is loth to make changes even with public instrumentalities. When the employees of private enterprise come before it, it may be in an anomalous position if it has granted 44 hours to public instrumentalities and for economic reasons decided to award 48 hours for private employees. Therein lies a ease for treatment of those employees in the Public Service by the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator, who is engaged exclusively in relationships between the public servants and the Crown. There is a great deal of contention that one cannot impose on private enterprise a shorter working week by any drastic decree of Parliament or by a declaration of the Commonwealth court that would have universal application; but I think I state the facts of the situation when I say that public policy should be primarily responsible for initiating a movement for the reduction of the working week, and that it would not be unreasonable for the Government, which a year ago proclaimed its adherence to a 40-hour week at an international conference, and even went so far as to ask its delegate to vote for a draft convention, the application of which would mean a 40- hour week, not to be fearful that the Arbitrator would do a ruinous thing by granting 44 hours on the transcontinental railway and the Central Australian railway. No other thing would warrant the Government interfering with the law than the fear that it has that a 44-hour week may be introduced.
If that is not the truth of the matter then the Minister should tell us actually what reasons actuated the Government in bringing down this legislation.

Mr.LANE (Barton) [9.40].- It seems to me that the question this House is called upon to decide is whether the Government is doing right in transferring the Commonwealth railway employees from one industrial tribunal to another. If in the view of the Government, the Public Service Arbitrator's court is not the jurisdiction to which the employees of the Commonwealth railway service should apply for altered conditions, then I think that they are entitled to be brought under the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration court. I do not agree with honorable gentlemen who tell me that the Arbitration Court is not the proper place for this matter to be dealt with. When all other railways are dealt with under the arbitration laws it is wise and well to leave the Commonwealth railways under the same jurisdiction. I have always been a supporter of the arbitration movement. I believe it is the best method by which industrial disputes can be settled, despite the fact that experience has been that when an Arbitration Court award is brought into operation and it does not suit either side, very often either one of them will have recourse to lockouts or strikes. I still believe, however, that arbitration is the only method by which industry can proceed on safe lines. Nevertheless it does appear that an obligation has been placed on the Government to see that restoration of conditions is made in the railway service through the medium of the court. First of all, the Government has agreed to district allowances and long-service leave. I have been asking myself why the Commissioner was ever instructed to oppose these conditions during the last few years. The Government readily said to-day that it would grant these concessions, and after all, if application is made to r,he Arbitration Court for conditions the employee makes his claim and the employer sets out the case in answer to it. The Government to-day is under an obligation to introduce a 44-hour week in this industry. We are talking about a 40-hour week for all industries throughout Australia and, in fact, there has been talk about an international scheme to bring this about. Just about 30 years ago we first heard about a 48- hour week and for many years that has had universal application to industry. For the last ten years, the agitation for a 44-hour working week has been persisted in with such success that, throughout a large field of industry, the 44-hour week now prevails. There ought (o bp. no activity under the control of the Commonwealth Government in which the working week is longer than 44 hours. I. do not know whether this necessary reform can be instituted by this Parliament, but there should be no furtherdelay in taking what steps are necessary to have it brought about through the proper channels. For my part, I cannot see why the railway employees should not be able to have their grievances redressed by the Commonwealth Arbition Court in place of the Public Service Arbitrator. In the final analysis, it depends largely upon the attitude of the Government. No doubt, the Government will say that it does not use its influence in these matters, but we know that, in fact, the Railways Commissioner consults with the Minister, and an understanding is reached between them as to what the Commissioner will accept, and what he will decline. The finances of the country have been so buoyant lately that the Government should experience no difficulty in granting this concession. T was appalled to learn of the conditions under which Commonwealth railway employees are living and working, and I cannot understand what successive Ministers for Railways have been doing to permit such conditions to continue. The great disadvantage under which public departments of this kind labour is the lack of business capacity in the men who control them, many of whom are, in effect, square pegs in round holes. It should not be necessary to appeal to the Arbitration Court for these conditions. The best possible conditions should be granted by the Government itself. I have always believed that the system of wages boards introduced by Charles Gregory Wade was much better for all parties concerned than the arbitration system. On the wages boards the representatives of the employers sat at the table side by side with the' representatives of the employees, and between them they reached an agreement concerning wages and conditions. There were no lawyers and no judges to make a fat living out of industrial litigation. The Government should, without delay, intimate its readiness to agree to a 44-hour week for railway employees.
Mr. Rosevear.- Will the honorable member vote for that?

Mr. LANE.- The honorable member knows that we shall have no opportunity to vote on that issue, but if, by my own act, it were possible to establish a 44-hour working week to-morrow, I should do so. I was distressed to heaT the honorable member for Grey (Mr. McBride) state that many of the employees on the Commonwealth railways were living in hovels. That state of affairs does not reflect much credit on the Government, or on the Ministers who have been in charge of the department. The men working on this long stretch of line under the most severe conditions lack even satisfactory education facilities for their children, and they cannot send their families away for rest or change. At the very least, then, they should be provided with decent homes to live in. If this charge had been made by honorable members of the party opposite, we might have thought it was exaggerated; but when the honorable member for Grey declares from his place in tha House that the conditions under which the railway men are working and living are a disgrace to the Government, it behoves the Government to see that something is done without delay. I hope that the Commissioner will not oppose the just claims of the employees.

Mr. BEASLEY*(West Sydney) [9.55] . - I have listened carefully to this discussion in an attempt to ascertain just what reason prompted the Government to introduce this legislation, the purpose of which is to deprive a section of Commonwealth railway employees of access to the Public Service Arbitrator. The Minister who introduced the bill (Mr. Hughes) said that the Government was actuated by a desire to bring about uniform conditions in the railway services throughout the Commonwealth, but the. speeches of the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford), who has been so closely associated with this case, and of the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Blackburn), throw an entirely new light on the matter. I find that the locomotive men's union presented a memorial to the Public Service Arbitrator on the 19th December, 1935, and that answers the interjection of the Minister, who asked the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin) when the claim was actually lodged. The other unions followed the locomotive men's union, but there is no doubt that the initial step was taken on the 19th December last by this organization. Other unions concerned followed in due course. However, when the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner learned that one of the main points of the claim was the reduction of the number of hours, he took steps to have the application heard before another tribunal. It is clear now that the Commissioner realised that he did not have a sufficiently strong case successfully to oppose the application of the locomotive men before the Public Service Arbitrator on the hours question. Like the honorable member for Parramatta (Sir Frederick Stewart), I have never been able to understand why there should be such a difference between the hours and conditions of work enjoyed by the inside, or collarandtie workers, and those of the men who work in overalls. The strain on the manual workers, especially locomotive men, is far more severe than on those who work in the central office or at railway stations. This differentiation still persists, however, and the Commissioner is determined to prevent the locomotive men from gaining a 44-hour working week. Apparently the Public Service Arbitrator knows too much about the internal conditions of the railway service to suit the Commissioner, who is anxious to take the case before the judges of the Arbitration Court, with whose opinions and prejudices he is familiar. He has, apparently, in the past, received favorable treatment from them, and he hopes to be treated as well again. It is quite clear to most of us that the Commissioner is the driving force behind the decision of the Government to introduce this legislation.
Mr. Drakeford.- Why should the Government take its stand against the claim of the employees?

Mr. BEASLEY.- That is a question which the Minister must answer. Why should the Government back up the Commissioner in his opposition to the introduction of a 44-hour week, when it' claims to have expressed itself in favour of the general introduction of a 40-hour week? It would appear that a majority of the members of the Government are in favour of removing this case to the Arbitration

Court, because they know that the court is opposed to the principle of a reduction of the number of working hours. When the union lodged its claim on the 19th December last, it raised the question of the legal right of the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner to force the employees into the Arbitration Court. I understand that the locomotive enginemen produced a legal opinion to the effect that the Railways Commissioner had no right to prevent them from having access to the Public Service Arbitrator, since their claims had already been lodged with that tribunal.
Mr Drakeford.- The opinion they obtained was that they could not be kept away from the Arbitrator because of the objection of the Railways Commissioner to their claims being heard by that tribunal.

Mr. BEASLEY.- That may be the strictly correct version, but I think I have conveyed a similar impression. According to my information, the Railways Commissioner also sought legal advice on this matter. I believe that further consultation on the legal position was to have taken place, but the representatives of the employees have not yet been advised regarding it, nor has the Railways Commissioner honoured his undertaking to inform them as to the legal opinion he had received. The only answer which the men have had from the Commissioner as to the legal position is the measure which has now been submitted to this House. This action by the Government calls for condemnation by those who ask for clean and straight dealing in matters affecting employees in the Commonwealth service. All the remarks by the Minister in charge of the bill as to the desirability of uniform conditions go by the board, because, even in the Commonwealth Railways Service, the conditions are not at all uniform. It seems that steps have been taken to prevent the locomotive men from having access to a tribunal which is available to other sections of the Public Service. Despite the doubt expressed as to the legal right of the Railways Commissioner to force the railway men into the Arbitration Court, the Government is seeking special legislation, at the very end of the session, for the purpose of giving the Commissioner a right which he did not possess when the employees' application was made on the 19th December last. This is an action of the worst kind.

I cannot say one word in favour of the Railways Commissioner, because, when a question was recently asked in this chamber as to why an air-conditioning plant for the Commonwealth Railways had been installed by an overseas firm, and when it was explained that a local manufacturer could have supplied the equipment at a price 25 per cent, lower than that of the overseas firm, the answer given was that the Railways Commissioner was unaware that such a plant could be manufactured in Australia.
Mr. Paterson.- He was unintentionally misled by the Railways Commissioners of another State.

Mr. BEASLEY.-This is not an indictment of the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Paterson), but the action of. the Railways Commissioner shows a degree of incompetence that is remarkable. If an ordinary railway employee had been responsible for such a wasteful expenditure, he would, have been dismissed within 24 hours, but a highsalaried officer seems to be able to do such a thing with impunity. The fact that the Railways Commissioner took steps to force these . men into the Arbitration Court before he knew whether he had authority to do so affords another indication of incompetence on his part. He proceeded on lines which he had no legal right to follow, and now the Government seeks to legalize the action taken. Honorable members should not support a measure of this kind. Discredit is reflected upon the Government for attempting to justify the Commissioner's action by eleventh-hour legislation.

Mr. PATERSON(Gippsland- Minister for the Interior) [10.8]. - The honorable member for West Sydney (Mr. Beasley) has charged the Railways Commissioner with having obtained an imported air-conditioning plant for the transcontinental railway service when such a plant could have been purchased in Australia. I can assure the House that, at the time when the order was given, the Commissioner was honestly of the opinion that the local firm bad had no experience whatever in the instalment of air-conditioning plants on trains. He considered that its experience was confined to offices, whilst the British firm, to whom the order was given for a trial plant, had had experience of railway installations. The Commissioner merely took advantage of the visit of a representative of a British firm, at the invitation of the Railways Commissioners of Victoria, to have a trial plant installed on the Transcontinental line. If further installations of air-conditioning plants are to be made on Commonwealth railways, the Australian firm will he given every opportunity to tender for them.

A good deal has been said about the Arbitration Court and' the Public Service Arbitrator. Everybody who has given thought to this matter must agree that the choice should be between one or the other, and that both should not remain in the field. All the weight of argument is undoubtedly in favour of the court, to which two-thirds of the railway workers of Australia take their claims. The Public: Service Arbitrator is accustomed to dealing with clerical workers, but the Arbitration Court has had a long experience of conditions on the various railways of Australia.

I rose, particularly, to reply to statements made regarding the conditions under which employees on the Transcontinental railway and other Commonwealth lines work. It has been said that these conditions compare unfavorably with those obtaining in other railway services in this country. Admittedly, the climatic conditions experienced on the Commonwealth railways are not so agreeable as those in other railway services, but even the honorable member for West Sydney would not blame the Railways Commissioner for the Australian climate. In addition to these natural drawbacks, one has to consider some of the special advantages enjoyed by Commonwealth railway employees, although little has been said about them. It was pointed out bv the honorable member for Grey (Mr. MoBride) that some compensation in the shape of pay should be made to men who work under the trying climatic conditions experienced on the Commonwealth railways. The district allowance runs up to as much as 12s. 3d. a week, increasing as the place of employment becomes further from Kalgoorlie, at the one end, or Port Augusta, at the other end. The allowance amounts to a fairly high figure on the Central Australian railway, and on the Northern Territory railway. Apart from long leave, which the Government has decided to grant to its railway employees, the ordinary annual leave is somewhat more generous than in other parts of Australia. There are now ten public holidays for which pay is received, a further nine days' recreation leave, and from one to five days which are allowed for travelling time, making a ,total of from 20 to 24 days per annum, including travelling time. Men employed on the Transcontinental line, at any considerable distance from either terminus, receive from one to five days' travelling time. That allowance was made when the line was being constructed, and when a considerable period was occupied in travelling on slow trains, or on goods trains between the place of employment and the nearest terminus. That travelling time has never been reduced, although it might have been fairly curtailed, in view of the fact that to-day we have relatively fast trains, and at least part of the time allowed is saved by the employees, because it is not actually taken up in travelling. Therefore, the allowance of from 20 to 24 days' annual leave compares more than favorably with that made to employees on other railway systems in Australia.

Reference has been made by the honorable member for Grey and others to the housing conditions on the Transcontinental railway. It is true that, in some instances, the accommodation is not all that could be desired. Even in this capital city of Canberra, we find houses of which we are not proud, and which we hope to have replaced as soon as possible by something a good deal better. On the Transcontinental railway a substantial improvement has been made in regard to the housing conditions of the employees. At Rawlinna, Cook and Tarcoola are to Iv seen some excellent cottages, but, even at other places, where the accommodation is not so good, it is not so bad as it seems to be. The worst feature is the outside appearance. Take for instance, what is called the double tent house, which is not a tent, but a weatherboard house with a double iron roof. This dwelling is Tshaped. It has a porch in the centre, with a room on either side. There is another large porch at the rear, which can be used for a room; and beyond that is a kitchen. These double tent houses, which are very simple in construction, cost the department about £280.
Mr. Gander.- What rent is charged for them?

Mr. PATERSON. - The rent is 2s. a week or £5 4s. per annum. If the honorable gentleman cares to compute what interest that represents on a capital cost of £280, he will find that it is only If per cent., which I do not think he would regard unduly high. The rent of the single tent houses is ls. a week. It must therefore be admitted that accommodation is provided for the workers at a very cheap rate. In addition to that, workers engaged in districts where firewood is not readily obtainable are provided with free firewood, and in waterless districts, where it costs a great deal to provide water, they are also provided free with that necessary commodity. Prices of groceries, due to the excellent organization of the Commonwealth Railway Department, compare favorably with those charged in Adelaide and suburbs. The price charged for meat in remote localities is not greater than that charged at Kalgoorlie, Port Augusta or Quorn. Fruit and vegetables are carried freight free to employees on the Transcontinental line. Honorable members will, therefore, realize that something is being done to make life as tolerable as possible for these people. Mention was made by the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) of the lack of provision for the sick. As a matter of fact, in cases of sickness, not only the employees, but also 'their wives and dependants are transported free, on trains running either to Port Augusta at one end of the line, or Kalgoorlie at the other, depending on which hospital happens to be the nearer.
Mr. Holloway.- I was referring to the northern section of the North-South line.

Mr. PATERSON.-I think the same conditions apply over the whole Commonwealth system. When a special section car has to be used part of the cost has to be borne by the employee, but that does not apply when a train is available.
Mr. Holloway.- The conditions must have been altered quite recently.

Mr. PATERSON.-That is the present position. A good deal has been said about the hardship inflicted on railway employees by reason of climatic conditions and the prevalence of flies. We all admit that those are real drawbacks, yet the fact remains that the people concerned are not nearly so sorry for themselves as we are for them. Most of them do not leave the climate to which they have been accustomed. When they get their annual leave, many of these men go only perhaps two stations further along the line and spend their holidays with railway friends living in the same climate in which they have been working for many years.
Mr. Drakeford.- They have not enough money to go further.

Mr. PATERSON.-They do not need it; they are provided with a free pass over the Commonwealth system and when they desire to travel on the State systems, they are charged one quarter of the ordinary passenger rate. It must be admitted that every facility is afforded these men to travel as cheaply as possible. The honorable member for Barton (Mr. Lane) referred to what lie said was a fact - it is not a fact - that the Commonwealth Railways' Commissioner had been instructed by the Government to oppose the granting of long service leave. The Government has never given the Commissioner any such instruction. On the contrary, as the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) has already indicated, the Government proposes to take steps to grant the men long-service leave. In considering what long-service leave should be granted, the Government had before it the practice adopted by the various States, and in arriving at a decision, did not. strike a mean between the most generous and the least generous treatment accorded by the different States; it did not even adopt the average, but decided to give to its own employees the long-service leave conditions enjoyed by the Western Australian railway servants, the most generous obtaining in any of the States. The Government is treating Commonwealth Railways servants fairly, and it intends to continue to do so. It regards these men as employees whom it is its duty to treat fairly. Nothing in the bill now before the House can be regarded as other than giving these men a fair deal.
Sir FrederickStewart. - Will thu Government instruct the Railways Commissioner not to oppose the claim of the men for a 44-hour week?

Mr. ROSEVEAR(Dalley) [10.24].- When the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Paterson) was speaking, I expected at least that we should hear something of the bill which so vitally affects Government servants under his control ; instead of dealing with the merits or the demerits of the bill before the House, the honorable member merely compared the conditions prevailing in the State railway services with those applying in the Commonwealth service, a matter quite beside the point at issue. The only question we have to deal with is whether the right of the Commonwealth Railways employees to appear before the Public Service Arbitrator, which they have enjoyed for sixteen years, should be taken away from them. That was a subject, however, upon which the Minister had least to say. His only observation was that the men should have the right to appear either before one tribunal or the other, which, in effect, means that their choice should be limited to the right to appear either before the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, or the Public Service Arbitrator. I am one of those who believe that when a man enjoys a right given to him by the Government, his liberty to exercise that right should not be questioned. In this case, the men had a perfect right to make a choice as to which tribunal they should approach, but that right is to be taken away from them in the bill now before the House. In view of the fact that all the men have to sell is their labour power, if they have the choice of approaching one tribunal or the other, to have the price of their labour fixed, why should they not enjoy that' privilege to the fullest extent? Assume that these men, instead of being engaged in running them, were actually engaged in the building of engines and carriages for sale; would the Minister say that the right of the Government should be limited to selling the products of their labour in one particular Stateor country; or if the Government controlling these works had the right to sell trains, would the Minister say that itsright should be restricted to sales in oneState or another ? Of course not ! These men did not seek the privilege of being able to make a choice; it was given to them by the Government. They had the alternative of approaching either the Commonwealth Arbitration Court or the Public Service Arbitrator, and it is the duty of both of those tribunals to fix conditions under which men will sell their labour power. If these men were working for a private employer, would the Minister restrict the right of the private employer to sell the goods which they produced in any particular market, or in any State or country? On the contrary, he would say that the employer had a perfect right to sell his goods in any market, or to retain them. The Commonwealth railway employees have never sought to go to both tribunals at the one time. The fact is they could not. Their agreement under an award of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court has expired, and they have filed a claim with the alternative tribunal, the Public Service Arbitrator. I could understand it if this bill had been brought in last year, when the Minister must have known that, sooner or later, these men would have to approach one of the two tribunals. But that was not done. The Commonwealth railway employees filed a claim last December, and I understand the proceedings reached a stage at which a compulsory conference has been held. The intervention of the Government at this stage of the hearing is most suspicious. The railway employees are not exercising a double choice for they have actually, and for good reasons, spurned the Commonwealth Arbitration. Court. Personally, I commend them for doing so, because of the experience they had three years ago when the judge who made an award for them disregarded the clear provision of the law with the result that his award was subsequently declared ultra vires the act by the High Court. In such circumstances,

I would not care whether these men had for sixteen years or 60 years submitted their claims to the Arbitration Court. When actual experience shows a man the futility of doing a certain thing he is surely at liberty to change his mind and' adopt an alternative. The Commonwealth railway employees have changed their minds as they were thoroughly entitled to do. It has been suggested that the men have gone to the Public Service Arbitrator because they know they will get a more favorable award from him, but there is no ground for such an assumption. We do not know' how the Arbitrator will regard the claim submitted to him. The true reason why the Public Service Arbitrator has been approached is that the men have lost all confidence in the Commonwealth Arbitration Court.

We have been assured that these cognate bills have been introduced solely in the interests of industrial uniformity, but that argument cannot be substantiated. If the Government desires to achieve a substantial degree of uniformity it can do so very easily in regard to its railway employees. In any case, complete uniformity is never likely to be realized, because wage rates in the various States vary according to prevailing price levels in the capital cities. Moreover, climatic conditions and certain other considerations affect wage rates. When we speak of uniformity we have in mind a uniform basic wage and working week. The honorable member for Bass (Mr. Barnard) pointed out early in this debate that the vast majority of the_ railway workers of Australia are enjoying a 44-hour working week. As the only parties that will be affected by the passage of this bill are the Government and its railway employees, I suggest that a provision be inserted in the 'bill to the effect that a 44-hour week shall be uniformly adopted throughout the Commonwealth railway system.
Mr.Archie Cameron. - I understood that the policy of the honorable member's party was a 40-hour working week.

Mr. ROSEVEAR.-If we had- the numbers in this Parliament, the honorable member for Barker (Mr. Archie Cameron) would very soon realize that that is our policy, but as we are not in that fortunate position, we are suggesting a 44-hour week for the Commonwealth railway employees as an advance on the 48 hours worked at present, so that at least that measure of uniformity can be achieved. If the Government feels that for any reason it cannot agree to the insertion of such a provision in this bill, I suggest that it direct the Railways Commissioner not to oppose the application of its railways employees for a 44-hour week.

I do not desire to discuss in detail the points raised by the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Paterson) in regard to working conditions on the East-West railway. I am prepared to accept the honorable gentleman's assurance that probably not half of the workers on that line travel more than a couple of stations from their home when they take their annual leave, but that is probably due to lack of cash. Probably 75 per cent, of the railway and tramway employees of New South Wales who also are entitled' to a free pass on the railways when on annual leave, are unable to take advantage of it : they cannot go far from their homes because they have not the money to take a holiday. However, all this is beside the issue that is before us.

The Government has not indicated clearly why it wishes to deprive its railway employees of the right, which they have enjoyed for the last sixteen years, of submitting their claims to the Public Service Arbitrator. If its intention is simply to limit the railway employees to one tribunal, it should, in the circumstances which face us, have taken steps to deprive them of the right to approach the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. Its action in intruding in a claim that is part heard is most reprehensible. The Commonwealth railway employees, having had such an unsatisfactory experience with the Commonwealth Arbitration Court in recent years, have approached the Public Service Arbitrator in the hope that substantial justice will be done them, and their action should not have been rudely assailed in this way.
Mr. MARTENS(Herbert) [10.44].- T consider that the Government has introduced these cognate measures because it fears that the Public Service Arbitrator may make an award favorable to the

Commonwealth railway employees. Three years ago, when an award favorable to its employees was made, steps were taken to have it disallowed, and I suppose the Government does not wish to be forced to do such an unpopular thing again. The ridicule which the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Blain) poured on the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) because he advocated industrial uniformity showed a complete misunderstanding of the situation. When we say that we desire uniformity in wages and working hours, we have in mind the basic wage and the standard working week. We do not suggest that variations in both wages and working hours should not be made to meet the peculiar circumstances of particular districts.

In the awards of every arbitration court, as well as of the Public Service Arbitrator, special provision is made to meet the case of those who are stationed in far-away places, and are working under adverse climatic and other conditions. In Queensland, a very substantial concession is granted by the Railways Commissioner in regard to the fares charged for the transport of the womenfolk of employees who are stationed in the outlying portions of that great State. Where the distance is over 200 miles, one-quarter fare is charged for the transport of wives and children to the places to which they wish to travel. Does the honorable member for the Northern Territory object to locomotive-drivers, firemen and guards working the same number of hours as are worked by the tradesmen who are responsible for the coachbuilding and the engineering and fitting work? I do not think that he would favour differentiation. He has related some of his experiences. I, too, have had a certain degree of experience, which enables me to say that, if there is one man more than another in the traffic department of any State railway service who should have a shorter working week, it is the engine-driver or the fireman. His work imposes a greater strain on the nervous system than is imposed by any other occupation of which I have knowledge.
The honorable member for Parramatta {Sir Frederick Stewart) asked the

Minister for the Interior (Mr. Paterson) whether he would promise that the Government would instruct the Commissioner not to oppose the granting of a 44-hour week. I suggest that, if that were done, no judge of an arbitration court, whether federal or other, would fail to realize that the Government was satisfied thai: that should be the standard number of hours in the railway services of Australia. That is all that the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) meant when he spoke of uniform conditions. Other conditions must be regulated by the tribunal which has the determination of the matter. This case having been submitted to the Public Service Arbitrator, the Government had not the right to interfere with it.. Claiming as it does that it has no wish to use political influence either with the Arbitration Court or with the Public ServiCe Arbitrator, it should be the last to interfere. It does not speak truthfully when it says that it does not wish to do so. The right honorable gentleman who is in charge of the measure (Mr. Hughes) has on more than one occasion, but on one in particular, interfered very definitely, in the past, with the functions of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. The honorable member for Melbourne Ports knows a good deal more industrially than the honorable member for the Northern Territory is ever likely to learn, because, in connexion with his activities in Australia and other countries on behalf of organized labour, he has had opportunities such as are presented to few men to study and report upon matters which affect the welfare of the workers. The Government would be on sound ground, and would act within its rights, were it to say to the Commissioner, " We shall not oppose the granting of a 44-hour week. Leave the matter to the arbitration tribunal."

A good case cannot be presented in favour of separate arbitration for the Public Service. I have said in this Parliament, and at many other places is. the Commonwealth, that there should nc be a separate tribunal to deal with the hours of labour and the other conditions of the Public Service. I do not consider that these matters are more intricate in the Public Service than. in other callings. The tribunal which is competent to determine the conditions of the mass of the workers is quite capable of adjudicating upon the conditions of every employee in Australia. In Queensland, there is not a special arbitrator for the Public Service; the wages and conditions of the large number of persons who are employed in the different public departments are determined by the Board of Trade and Arbitration. The conditions in regard to the minimum rates of pay and the maximum number of hours should be uniform in the case of every man employed in the railway service of the Commonwealth.

The circumstances in regard to housing related by the honorable members for Grey (Mr. McBride) and the Northern Territory are not peculiar to the Commonwealth Railways Department. It is a crying shame that they should be allowed to continue.

Mr. HUGHES(North SydneyMinister for Repatriation) [10.52 j. - in reply - This debate has proceeded along lines that appeal to me. There has been, a very earnest desire on the part of honorable members generally to discuss the matter on a plane free from all personali[les. Even though we have had some special privately-screened pictures of the past, and have been reminded of former utterances, that is all to .the good. One can learn something even from oneself, if one looks back at oneself in Drover nerspective

This legislation, which is part of a series introduced into this Parliament, has for its object the settlement of industrial disputes. It has evoked characteristic comment. Since the first of such measures was introduced in 1904, the people have been assured that dire consequences must inevitably result. I have just been refreshing my memory in regard to what was said in 1904, when the first Commonwealth Arbitration Bill was before this Parliament. Then, as now, the measure was bitterly assaulted. Then, and on every subsequent occasion,, a most remarkable ebullition of feeling has been displayed by gentlemen on the other side of the chamber. T am not suggesting that in every case they have been the gentlemen who now occupy those benches. But upon every occasion when 1 have stood here as the protagonist of a measure to amend, to amp! if y, to improve the arbitration system of this country, I have been assailed by vehement denunciations and suggestions of a fell and sinister purpose, intended to destroy the principles of justice and to impair those fair and alluring opportunities which, but for me or for people like me, would spread themselves before the workers of this country. All that has been said to-night was said when the first Commonwealth Arbitration Bill was before this Parliament in 1904 - from a different aspect, of course, but nevertheless, the same thing in substance. Then, too, when the 1911 measure, which I introduced, was before the chamber, we were assured that at best it should be viewed with profound, suspicion, that evidently there was behind, it a purpose which had not been revealed ;. just as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr.. Curtin) has said that the real purpose of this measure is to be found in the Machiavellian tactics of the Commissioner forRailways, who has seized upon this as a. convenient means for knifing the fairprospects of a 44-hour week. All that I. have to say is that the' real purpose- behind this bill is that set out in my speech. I can only deal with the bill itself, and with the facts asthey have been presented to me.. I repeat : .Show me where any substantial., injustice is to be done by this measure toany man. The Leader of the Opposition could not answer this question, but. countered it by asking me another. " Show me ", said he, " what injustice will be - done to the Commonwealth Railway Commissioner by the appearance of Common- - wealth railway employees before the Public Service Arbitrator." My reply is that no substantial injustice will be done to him, but that he is entitled to have the conditions under which the service - is to operate fixed by a competent tribunal. No tribunal can be- competent .. which has not statutory powers; which is* not able to make an award that cannot be overridden; and which is not well informed, experienced, and familiar with the complex conditions of modern railways. If we are to choose between these two tribunals, we are irresistibly driven to the conclusion that there is only one upon which the choice should fall. On the one hand there is a tribunal which for years has been dealing with railway conditions, and on the other hand there is the Public Service Arbitrator, who has a wide and an intimate knowledge of the affairs of the Public Service of the Commonwealth, but knows nothing whatever of the working conditions of the railway services throughout Australia. So I agree entirely with the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner in his demand that the circumstances under which he shall conduct his undertaking shall be fixed by the same court that fixes the conditions of four of the railway services of Australia, and in effect fixes the conditions of all the State railway systems of Australia; for, although it is true that the services of the States of Queensland and Western Australia are working under State industrial tribunals -not Public Service tribunals, mark you, but tribunals which are competent to deal with all disputes that arise within the territorial boundaries of those States - those tribunals make their determinations upon the basis established by the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. The proof of that is to be found in a statement which is available to honorable members if they choose to read it. Therefore, the conditions fixed by the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration are, in effect, the conditions which obtain in all he railway services of Australia.
Mr. Holloway.- Why, then, was it necessary to adopt some of the conditions that have been prescribed in Western Australia?

Mr. HUGHES.- We are merely asking that the same tribunal shall fix rates and conditions for the Commonwealth railways as fixes the rates and conditions of the railway systems of South Australia, Western Australia, Queensland or STew South Wales.

The honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) dealt at some "length with my long-expressed desire to have uniformity. The only way in which we can expect to achieve uniformity is by having conditions fixed by one court, not by ten courts.

The Leader of the Opposition said that the Government's proposals would not mean perfection, but I would impress on him that we are always endeavouring to achieve perfection. We have not done so yet, but are endeavouring to Teach that happy goal. Mankind is always striving and there is more joy in striving than in attainment.

The honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Blackburn) made a contribution to the debate which, because of his standing, reputation and familiarity with railway union cases, no doubt carried much weight. He said two things to which I must refer. One of them was that he did not accept the assurance that the amendment made by the Statute Law Revision Act by which the words "in that act " were struck out was inadvertent.
Mr. Blackburn.- If the right honorable gentleman says himself that it was inadvertent, I shall accept it. Otherwise I shall not.

Mr. HUGHES.-The honorable member knows perfectly well, because he knows the way the Crown Law Department works, that I would have no personal cognizance of the drafting of the Statute Law Revision Bill. I have to speak as I am advised, but I have confirmed my previous statement that neither did the department, when making that alteration, have any idea of its effects, nor did it when that act was passed realize what had been done.
Mr. Blackburn.- In almost twenty years of political experience, I have never encountered such an explanation as that before.

Mr. HUGHES.-The honorable member also said that in taking away the right of the railway men to go to the Public Service Arbitrator, this Government, as it were, had violated a cardinal principle of justice. I do not think that the honorable member in a careful review of what his statement implies will maintain that. I ask him : What does Parliament do? How is reform effected? Is it some kid glove affair in which one carefully refrains from interfering with the rights of everybody? The honorable member's party rests upon such interference with existing rights as to put the fear of God into the rest of the community.
Mr. Blackburn.- I wanted this House to know that this legislation, deprives people of a right which this Parliament has approved.

Mr. HUGHES.- How could it deprive people of a right unless that right did exist? Let us see what the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1920 which set up the Public Service Arbitrator said under section 11. It said -

( 1 ) Notwithstanding anything contained in the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1911, an organization of employees in the Public Service shall not be entitled to submit to the court under that act any claim relating to the salaries, wages, rates of pay, or terms or conditions of service, or employment of members of the organization.

(2) All claims relating to the salaries, wages, rates of pay. or terms or conditions of service or employment of members of any organization which are pending in the court at the commencement of this act, other than claims the hearing of which has been commenced by the court, shall be byforce; of act transferred to the Arbitrator, and shall be deemed to have been submitted to the Arbitrator in pursuance of this act.
In the present instance a memorial was filed, but the case had not been started. Consequently nothing has. been done.
Mr. Drakeford.- The Minister has been misinformed. A conference with the Arbitrator had taken place.

Mr. HUGHES.- That was only a preliminary proceeding. It was not the commencement of the hearing of the case. However, I do not intend to delay the House. "Whatever wind blows in this direction, I am satisfied the Commonwealth railway workers will consider that on the whole it will turn out to be a better wind than has blown their way for many years, for it gives to them long-service leave, which they would not get in any other way. It has been suggested that we should not " spoil the ship for a ha'porth o' tar " and that we should go from strength to strength, and grant a 44-hour week. About that I say nothing, except to express mild astonishment that the Opposition would now be satisfied with 44 hours when the other day, it was demanding 40 hours. I suggest that it be content with what it has, and pray for better things.
Question - That the bill be now read a second time - put. The House divided. (Mr. Speaker - Hon. G. j. Bell.)
Majority...... 12
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 and 2 agreed to.
Mr.BLACKBURN (Bourke) [11.12]. - I move -

That the following new clause be inserted: - " (3) This act shall nut affect the power of the Public Service Arbitrator to determine any claim which has been submitted to him pursuant to the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1920-1934 before the passing of this act".

The object of this new clause is to preserve the right of the unions to proceed with the claims which they have already lodged. In accordance with sub-section 2 of section 12 of the Arbitration (Public Service) Act, the unions lodged a claim by memorial, and the Public Service Arbitrator is obliged, in the terms of the act, to determine the matter submitted to him. The position is the same as if a plaintiff had begun an action in a court. It i3 not a question of altering the law so that a right of action does not exist in future; it is a question of altering the law to take away a right of action which has already been begun. Of course, the law can do that, but it does not as a rule do it. Such action is considered to be unjust, and on a plane with taking away a man's property without compensation. During my speech on the second-reading stage of the bill, I mentioned the action taken by the Minister for Health (Mr. Hughes) in connexion with the Arbitration Act, when it was proposed to prevent a single judge from altering standard hours. The amending section contained a provision that the alteration would not affect proceedings which were then being heard. The principle is well recognized by the English courts. Parliament is not presumed to intend to take away rights to proceed with actions which have been already commenced. It can do so, but the act must clearly show that such is the intention of Parliament. "Without the amendment which I have moved, this measure would clearly indicate that intention. I think that it is only right that these proceedings which have already commenced should be allowed to continue. T refer the committee to a point which illustrates this matter very well. At the beginning of this century, an action was decided by the Supreme Court of Queensland, and the unsuccessful party had a right of appeal to the Privy Council. Then the Commonwealth Judiciary Act was passed, taking away the right of appeal to the Privy Council, and substituting for it a right of appeal to the High Court. Nevertheless, the appellant went before the Privy Council, and the Council held that he had the right so to appeal to it. The Council admitted that the legislature had the power to take away that right, but pointed out that it was a principle of English law that the legislature must be presumed not to have intended to take the right away unless that intention was clearly stated in the act. In one case, a very distinguished English judge, Mr. Baron Pollock, said -

It certainly was considered in many cases that where a person had commenced an action he had a vested right, and that any subsequent statute ought not to be construed as retro-active so as to alter that right. That is not an invariable rule, and it will not apply whore the language of the statute is clearly expressed.

If my amendment is agreed to, the Public Service Arbitrator will be obliged to hear those claims that have been already lodged, but all future claims will go before the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. Another case was decided by a distinguished authority, Mr. Baron Channell, who said that, in dealing with acts of Parliament which have the effect of taking away rights of action, we ought not to construe them as having a retrospective operation,, unless it appears clearly that such was the intention of the legislature. The cases which I have cited effectively support my view that the Government should not, as a matter of policy, so alter the law as to destroy the right of persons to proceed with actions already commenced.

Mr.MARTENS (Herbert) [11.20].- I support the amendment. Notwithstanding what the right honorable member in charge of the bill (Mr. Hughes) has said, it has been clearly established that action had been commenced before this legislation was introduced. The Arbitrator had ordered the parties into conference, and action had been commenced. With all due deference to the right honorable Minister, I say that arguments which were adduced in 1904 do not now apply, because arbitration was then in its infancy. In this case the parties had taken the necessary steps for the purpose of having an award framed governing the conditions under which they were working, and it illbecomes this Government to intervene with legislation which denies the right of action to these men. If we had attempted to discuss a case which was before the courts, the right honorable member would at once have reminded us that the matter was sub judice. Nevertheless, this Government is now using its power to deny the right of action to unions which have already commenced an action in a properlyconstituted court of this country.

Mr. HUGHES(North Sydney- Minister for Repatriation) [11.24]. - I am unable to accept the amendment. The point which the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Blackburn) has been making is based upon a rule of construction where the intention of the legislature is not clear, but here the intention of the legislation is clear. No new ground has been broken. Section 11 of the 1920 act created exactly the same position. Under that act all the cases listed were dismissed and passed over to the newly-constituted court, and parties who had filed actions were denied access to the court. Only those cases which were part heard were carried forward.

Mr. DRAKEFORD(Maribyrnong) [11.25]. - I was hoping that the right honorable Minister in charge of the bill (Mr. Hughes) would accept the amendment, because, as the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Blackburn) has shown, the railway employees had established their right. Action had been commenced. Section 12 of the act provides -

12. - (1.) The Arbitrator shall, subject to the provisions of this section, determine all matters submitted to him relating to salaries, wages, rates of pay, or terms or conditions of service or employment of officers and employees of the Public Service. (2.) Any organization shall be entitled to submit to the Arbitrator by memorial any claim relating to the salaries, wages, rates of pay, or terms or conditions of service or employment of members of the organization. (3.) The Arbitrator shall forward a copy of the claim to the Commissioner, and to the Minister of any Department of State affected by the claim. (4.) The Commissioner and the Minister of any Department of State affected by the claim may within the prescribed time lodge, either jointly or separately, any objections they see fit to make to the granting of the claim.

The Commissioner did that. By lodging his objection to the claim he helped , the locomotive enginemen to initiate their proceedings. (5.) If any objection is lodged, the Arbitrator shall call a conference, to be presided over by himself, of representatives of the organization and of the Commissioner and of any Minister who has lodged objections to the granting of the claim, and following upon such conference shall, after hearing such evidence (if any) in respect of such matters as have .not been agreed to at the conference ae the Arbitrator thinks necessary, determine the claim.

The preliminary steps having been taken, the Arbitrator ordered the parties into conference, and the proceedings were actually commenced. The Minister has been misled if he says that the proceedings had not been commenced. We had established the right to be heard, and that right should be respected. This legislation should not have retrospective application. I am surprised at the Government's attitude. The men desire to have their claim decided by ' peaceful means. No body of employees could do more to hold up the transport services, if they were willing to take risks, than these men. They approve the policy of conciliation and arbitration, and expect to get at least justice; but this Government introduces legislation, the purpose of which is to interfere with their statutory rights. It is evident that some powerful and influential body moved this Government to introduce this legislation. This action is most unfair, and the greater the publicity given to it, the more clearly it will be seen that this Government stands for the employer as against 'the employee on every occasion. The right honorable gentleman who has introduced this bill has fought for the trade unions in the past; but, despite his splendid early record, he is now fighting for theemployer, and against the interests of unions which are seeking toadopt the peaceful methods of arbitration for which, he stood. The Public Service Arbitrator stated at the conference that a claim had been submitted to him by the union which covered the full range of the wages and conditions, of its members. He said that a copy of the claim was served on the respondent Commissioner, who had lodged a formal objection to the claim on the ground that an award of the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration already existed. That was award 109 of 1932. He further remarked that the Commissioner's objection had been stated in the briefest terms, and at that stage he invited the Commissioner to supplement his objections.' When the union submitted a legal opinion to justify its attitude, the

Commissioner said that he had a legal opinion too. We submitted our legal opinion, and, as requested, gave a copy of it to the Commissioner. After discussion, he undertook to supply us with the opinion on which he founded his belief that we had no right to go before the Public Service Arbitrator. We have never received the Commissioner's legal opinion. All we have had is this bill. The Minister is being used in order to help the employer in his efforts to circumvent the employees. I was one of those who advised the members of the union that, if they waited for the opportunity, they could approach the Public Service Arbitrator in order to get justice. Do not honorable members opposite consider that that was a proper attitude for the union officials to adopt? If the Minister were free to express his own. opinion on the matter, he would admit the validity of the argument adduced by the honorable member for Bourke, and say that what the union had done was the only right thing to do. If honorable members do what is proper, they will vote in favour of the amendment and insist on the union not being deprived of its rights.

Mr. MCBRIDE(Grey) [11.35].- Although I am in accord with the general provisions of this bill, as the Government has inadvertently prevented the union from taking any course other than that followed by it, I am prepared to support the amendment. I oppose retrospective legislation in principle, and, since the union has availed itself of the legal facilities open to it, the Government would be unwise in excluding it from the tribunal to which it has appealed.

Mr. CURTIN(Fremantle) [11.36].- The refusal of the Government to accept this reasonable amendment exposes the purpose of the bill. It is designed to prevent the Public Service Arbitrator from adjudicating on the submission now before him. This is an unprecedented action in connexion with arbitration proceedings in Australia. The determination of the Government to alter the law in respect of all future proceedings should be decided on its merits, and, although I should object to such a measure as this on . principle, I should consider it understandable to propose that, from now on, any union of railway employees which desired to submit a claim to arbitration should have to go to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. That is what this bill provides, but, up to this hour, the unions have had the legal right to go to the Public Service Arbitrator, and they have availed themselves of the option which the law gives. In a perfectly lawful way, and observing the awards hitherto made, they have said to themselves, " We may now go to the Public Service Arbitrator ". They have studied the act and have presented their memorial. Objections to it have been entered by the Railways Commissioner, presumably on behalf of the Government, the Arbitrator has dealt with the objections, and a compulsory conference has been called and held. It is idle to say that proceedings are not taking place, because the tribunal is now engaged in adjudicating on the merits of the submission. Recognizing that this measure provides that, for the future, the employees shall be restricted to the Arbitration Court, and shall no longer have the option hitherto enjoyed of going to the Public Service Arbitrator, the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Blackburn) claims that it is unfair to apply that principle during the hearing of a case now before the Arbitrator. The -Minister, in refusing to accept the amendment, compels me to make the reflection that this bill would not now be before us except for the desire of the Government to prevent the Arbitrator from dealing with the case submitted to him. The Government desires to deny to the Arbitrator the authority which the present law gives to him, and to deny to the unions a right which the law confers upon them, and which they are exercising. By that decision the right honorable gentleman, acting on behalf of the Government, is retrospectively destroying the vested interests of the trade union. What other vested interests would this Parliament so readily retrospectively destroy? It is not willing to give taxation legislation retrospective application. Honorable members occupying the corner bench would rise in their wrath if the

Government introduced a measure imposing taxation retrospectively, and it is therefore unjust to deprive the trade unionists of the rights they should be able to exercise under the law as it stands today. The Government with its majority can prevent this union from putting its case before the Public Service Arbitrator. It is showing a preference for an award, which it believes the Commonwealth CoUrt of Conciliation and Arbitration will make, and its fear of an award which might be made by the pub.lic Service. Arbitrator. I remind the right honorable gentleman that the court for which it is expressing a preference includes a judge who was once the president of the Employers Federation. I feel that this legislation- is not only drastic in character, but also designed deliberately to prevent the workers in this instrumentality from getting that measure of justice, which they feel that they can expect from the Public Service Arbitrator.

Mr. HUGHES(North Sydney- Minister for Repatriation) [11.42]. - I must confess that I am surprised at the versatility of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin), who ha3 infused into the discussion a vitality which is simply staggering. If one had wandered into this chamber when the Leader of the Opposition was speaking a few minutes ago, one would have imagined that we were faced with this problem for the first time, that we had been engaged for many hours this afternoon and evening upon some unimportant matter of detail, and that we had not got down to the great fundamental principles upon which he has now placed his finger. One would have imagined that earlier in the day we were not engaged on what he suggests is the foul business of stabbing trade unionists in the back. Honorable members opposite who have spoken have directed their remarks, not to something that we were to do in the future, but to something which we propose to do now. The Leader of the Opposition, in his second-reading speech on this measure, said, " What is the purpose behind the bill? The Minister has not told us, but it really is to prevent the Public Service Arbitrator from granting the railway men a 44-hour week ". Yet he now suggests that earlier in the debate we were dealing with abstract questions, and now for the first time were considering a concrete proposal, one whose purpose is to prevent the railway men from having their case heard by the Public Service Arbitrator, and that if that were clearly stated, his objection would not be so pronounced.
Mr. Curtin.- The right honorable gentleman knows perfectly well that the purpose of this measure is to prevent the railway men from going before the Public Service Arbitrator.

Mr. HUGHES.-The honorable gentleman made that point in his second-reading speech, and the amendment of the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Blackburn) raises no new point. The Leader of the Opposition knows what section 11 of the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1920 provides. What was said when that measure was before the Parliament is being repeated now.

Mr. Curtin.- The right honorable gentleman is misrepresenting the position, as section 11, sub-section 2, of the principal act referred to claims which were pending other than claims the hearing of which had been commenced by the court.
Mr. HUGHES-The rights which the men had were taken away from them.
Mr. Curtin.- Not in the cases that, were commenced.
Mr. HUGHES.-Does the Leader of the Opposition say that this case has commenced ?
Mr. Curtin.- Yes.

Mr. HUGHES.-The honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford), in supporting the amendment moved by the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Blackburn), said that this case had commenced, and that I had been misinformed. It is the honorable member who has been misinformed. This is a question of fact and not of opinion. Is it a fact that this case has in law commenced ?
Mr. Beasley.- Yes, on the 19th of September.
Mr. HUGHES.- My information is that the case has not commenced.
Mr. Beasley.- The information of the right honorable gentleman is wrong.
Mr. HUGHES.-My information is very definite on that point.
Mr. Curtin.- Was a compulsory conference held on the 31st January ?
Mr. HUGHES.- I cannot say.
Mr. Drakeford.- I can, because I attended that conference as the representative of the union.
Mr. HUGHES.-That does not prove that the case was commenced.
Mr. Drakeford.- It does.

Mr. HUGHES.- It does not. My point is that the hearing of the merits of the case had not been commenced and therefore no injustice is done and none can be done by transferring to another tribunal. On that the Government stands. If the honorable member for Bourke is able to dispute that position let him do so. It is a question of fact and I am perfectly prepared to wait for further information. The whole argument of the honorable member for Bourke breaks down if the case, on its merits, has not been commenced.

Mr.BLACKBURN' (Bourke) [11.52]. - -Section 12 of the Public Service (Arbitration) Act provides that the Arbitrator is to determine claims submitted to him under the act. The next sub-section provides that claims are to be submitted by a union by a memorial. If no objection is made the Arbitrator decides in favour of the union, but if the Railway Commissioner makes an objection the Arbitrator calls a conference at which the parties discuss matters with the object of arriving at an agreement. If no agreement is arrived at and if the matters are not completed he then proceeds to hear evidence. In this instance the proceedings have been commenced by the serving of the claim which has resulted in the calling of a conference. The stage at which evidence is to be heard has not yet been reached. Nevertheless this matter has been commenced. As the Leader of the Opposition pointed out, in 1920 cases pending before the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, which was then the only possible tribunal open to Commonwealth employees before the public servants were transferred to the Arbitrator, the Commonwealth Arbitration Court was permitted to continue the hearing of the cases which it had begun. The act expressly preserved the existing right of the unions to continue their cases in the Arbitration Court. The right honorable gentleman now concedes the principle for which I have been contending. He says that it only applies to the actual hearing on the merits. In Irving's case, the Queensland case, to which I referred earlier, there was only notice of appeal given to the Privy Council. Legislation had been passed by this Parliament purporting to remove the right to appeal to the Privy Council generally, and giving the right of appeal to the High Court. This case came before the Privy Council, and the respondents answering the appeal said, " This matter is barred by the legislation passed by the Commonwealth Parliament. The Commonwealth Parliament has passed a law taking away the right of appeal to the Council, and substituted in its place the right of appeal to the High Court." The Privy Council said, " The right of appeal is a man's right, which Parliament does not take away without expressing its intention in clear language. There is no clear language here. Therefore the right of appeal to the Privy Council remains. It cannot be said that right of appeal to the High Court was intended to be a substitute for an existing right of appeal to the Privy Council." If Parliament likes to act retrospectively, and take away a man's right, it has the power to do so; but to take away a man's rights is similar to taking away his liberty. The Minister suggests to us that the Commonwealth Commissioner for Railways is faced with immense difficulties in trying to get this matter dealt with by the Arbitration Court. The Commissioner in 1933 tried to stop the unions going to the Arbitration Court and legislation was brought down in an attempt to block them. The present attitude on the part of the. Commissioner is a change from that formerly adopted. Each side has changed its attitude, and there are no merits involved except the question as to whether this Parliament should interfere with rights that have already accrued. .

Mr.HUGHES (North Sydney- Minister for Repatriation) [11.56]. - It is very difficult to distinguish the objections which are now taken from those which were urged during the second reading debate. The point I make is that nothing has been done by this measure which was not done by the Arbitration (Public Service) Act of 1920. The question is whether proceedings had been begun on their merits is ascertainable and I am perfectly willing to ascertain that information. I suggest that the best person "from whom, we can get it is the Arbitrator himself.
Mr. Blackburn.- There should be no objection to the Arbitrator being asked to say what he has done.
Mr. HUGHES.--We should ascertain whether as a fact, the Arbitrator had actually begun proceedings on the merits. We want the facts.
Mr. Blackburn.- I am afraid that the right honorable gentleman wants to trick us.
Mr. HUGHES.- With all respect we should not forget that the honorable member for Bourke appeared for these men in the court.
Mr. Blackburn.- That is not correct.

Mr. HUGHES.-It is true. All we desire to do is to get at the facts. The point is whether proceedings were actually commenced on their merits and I suggest that that information could be obtained from the Public Service Arbitrator. To enable that to be done, I am agreeable to report progress.
Mr. Blackburn.- Before doing so, 1 suggest that it is fair that the Public Service Arbitrator should be asked to say what he has done in the case; then the committee can decide for itself.
Progress reported.

debate.para: Boulia-Winton Telephone Lini! - Employment of Girls by Postal Department.

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: . - I desire to raise a matter which affects a large number of farmers and settlers in my electorate. Because these people are prepared to go on the land, the Postal Department, apparently, regards them as a " mob of suckers ", and not in their real light as producers. Representations have been made to the department by the Boulia and Winton Shire Councils for the erection of a proper telephone line between Boulia and Winton, a distance of about 200 miles, and these have been supported' by Senator Cooper and myself on various occasions during the last seven months. The Deputy Director of Posts and Telegraphs in Queensland wrote to the residents of this district asking what they estimated' the erection of this line would cost. They are workers and wool-growers, and not telephonic experts. During the last flood in this district a couple of persons died because weeks elapsed before medical aid could be summoned to attend to these cases. Both senator Cooper and I have tried every method to have the matter properly inquired into by the department, so as to obviate raising it in Parliament, but have failed. Without an inspection, the department has rejected the request.
- What telephone facilities now exist in the area?

- There is a treetotree line from Winton to Middleton, but from Middleton to Boulia, there is no line of any value. In the wet season, the people in the latter area have no means of communication, and one can imagine the feelings of the womenfolk out there when storm-clouds begin to gather. Much of the money granted by this Government to different States for the purpose of relieving unemployment has been paid for chipping grass off footpaths in and around metropolitan areas, this work being done at a time when people in many country districts have not even decent telephonic or mail facilities. If this matter is not attended to, I shall take every opportunity throughout the remainder of this session to ventilate it. Surely these people are entitled to an investigation into their request before it is turned down by dictators in the Public Service. As Boulia happens to be in an area, however, where officers would have to travel by buggy and pair, no inspection is made. While I am a member of this Parliament, I shall not be a party to allowing officialdom to adopt such methods. The department has stated that this proposition would not be a. payable one, as it would cost £28,000 and the revenue therefrom would not justify such an outlay. If this line were made available, 200 subscribers would take advantage of it. Surely it is not intended that our outback country must be devoloped on a £1 for £1 subsidy basis. The Government desires people to go into remote areas to develop the country, and when they do so rewards them with isolation instead of departmental telephonic facilities.

speech.para: Reconsideration should also be given to the conditions under which certain young people are appointed to positions in the Postal Department. Some time ago a girl was employed by the department at Mareeba on the condition that her services would be continued until she reached the age of 21 years unless an examination were held in the meantime. No examination was held until the girl bad been in the service for two years. She then offered herself as a candidate for appointment, but as she was obliged to work right up to the time of the examination, she was at a disadvantage compared with other girls who sat for the examination, and did not obtain one of the best passes. When temporary employment was made available to successful candidates she was overlooked, even though she had passed the examination. Evidently the policy of the department is to employ young people when they reach the age of sixteen or eighteen years and then dismiss them when they reach the age of 21 years. That is entirely unfair. Examinations should be held for appointment at sixteen years, and eighteen years, and candidates should be allowed to sit in all country towns. Those who succeed should have priority of appointment in their own towns. As things are, country children are at a considerable disadvantage compared with those who live in the metropolitan areas. I ask that the policy of the department in connexion with the employment of these young people be reviewed.

I have been informed that during the coming Parliamentary recess, the POStmasterGeneral intends to visit Townsville to participate in the ceremony oil the occasion of the official opening of the broadcasting station there. I ask that hetake the opportunity at that time to travel along the western railway line of Queensland as far as Winton, to ascertain for himself the conditions to which I have referred to-night, under which the settlers live in that area. If he does so I feel sure that he will be convinced that the telephone line for which I have asked should be provided without delay to encourage these scattered settlers who are doing their best to increase the wealth of the nation.

talk.start.para: . - I promise the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan) that I shall place before the Postmaster-General his request for a telephone line between Winton and Boulia. I shall also bringthe Hansard report of the honorable gentleman's speech under my colleague's notice, and ask that the fullest inquiry be made into the subject. Obviously some inquiry has already been made, for the honorable member referred to an estimate that had been prepared.
- No proper investigation, of the route has been made by an official of the department.
- I shall direct the Postmaster-General's attention to that observation. If action cannot be taken to provide this facility T shall ask that the reason why be communicated to the honorable member.
- The figures prepared by local people were made available toSenator Cooper by the Winton Chamberof Commerce.
- 1 shall also bring under the notice of the Postmaster-General the honorable member's suggestion that he should visit Winton.

speech.para: The remarks of the honorable member regarding the employment of youths and girls by the postal department will also be investigated. I assume that the honorable member is aware that certain regulations of the department provide that temporary employment of that character shall be only for specified periods. Good reasons can be advanced for that practice. The circumstances of the employment at Mareeba of the girl mentioned by the honorable member will be reviewed. I am sure that a reasonable explanation of the whole case will be forthcoming. I assure the honorable gentleman that it is not the policy of the Postal Department to discard inconsiderately the young people whom it employs in a temporary capacity.
